headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Kirby Corporation Fourth Quarter and Year Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Steve Holcomb. Mr. Holcomb, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Kirby Corporation Fourth Quarter and Year Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Steve Holcomb. Mr. Holcomb, you may begin.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me today is Berdon Lawrence, Kirby's Chairman; Joe Pyne, The President, Chief Executive Officer of Kirby; and Norman Nolen, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call,
componenttext: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me today is Berdon Lawrence, Kirby's Chairman; Joe Pyne, The President, Chief Executive Officer of Kirby; and Norman Nolen, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under non-GAAP Financial Data. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reason of judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risk and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2008 filed with the SEC. I will now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Steve. Blessed afternoon. We reported net earnings for the 2004 fourth quarter of $0.54 per share, compared to $0.72 per share reported for the same period the year before. Included in our fourth quarter results was a $0.05 per share char
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Steve. Blessed afternoon. We reported net earnings for the 2004 fourth quarter of $0.54 per share, compared to $0.72 per share reported for the same period the year before. Included in our fourth quarter results was a $0.05 per share charge for short staff reductions; a $0.02 per share charge for a partial, goodwill impairment of Osprey Lines. That's our container and barge operation; and a positive $0.02 per share net reduction in our allowance for doubtful accounts. Norman will discuss each of these in more detail in a few minutes. Our announced earnings guidance for the fourth quarter was $0.57 to $0.62 per share. For the year, we earned $2.34 per share, which compares to $2.91 for 2008. During the fourth quarter, our Marine Transportation volumes were slightly lower than the third quarter volumes and remained well below prior-year levels. Our barge utilization for the fourth quarter, which was impacted by weather, bounced in the range of the 80% to 85%. During the fourth quarter, the term contract portion of our revenue mix declined to approximately 75% from 80% reported for most of last year. Time charter's declined to approximately 50% of total term contracts. This was anticipated, as customers in some cases, switched to lower spot rate contract opportunities as their term contracts expired. Barging rates remained under pressure throughout the year. In the 2009 first quarter, first quarter of last year, we said that we were generally able to renew our contracts at flat rates. And in the cases that we reduced rates we traded rate per comp. Our second quarter, that was over. Term contracts were just down. Best case flat to 8% lower. Spot rates during that quarter declined in a range of 10% to 15% on a year-over-year basis. Spot rates include fuel. In the third quarter, contract rates renewed 7% to 15% lower. And spot rates continued to deteriorate in the 10% to 20% range on a year-over-year basis. In the last quarter, the fourth quarter, term contracts renewed again in the 7% to 15% range. But spot rates continue to decline and/or 20% to 30% below to where they were the prior year. We do sense that we're close to the bottom of pricing in our markets. But there is some further risk of erosion, and we are likely to experience continued rate pressure on term contract renewals at least for the first half of this year.While our Marine Transportation revenues declined $49 million during the fourth quarter and $214 million for the year when compared to 2008, approximately $16 million or 33% of the fourth quarter revenue decline, and $79 million or 37% of the year-revenue decline can be explained by lower fuel prices, which are passed through to the customer using fuel escalation and de-escalation causes in term contracts. And at least with respect to the 2009 year, those contracts have de-escalated.Delay days during the quarter increased about over 160%, compared to the third quarter. But we're in line with the delay days recorded in the same period a year before. 2009, with the exception of last quarter, was really a very good year for weather delays. Typically, we see more weather delays during the year. During 2009, we took the liberty of 43 new Kirby-owned tank barges and in addition to seven chartered barges. With the industry excess barge capacity and utilization issue, utilization in the range of 80% to 85%, with respect to Kirby, we retired 101 of our tank barges which resulted in approximately 5.5% reduction in our barge fleet. As of the end of 2009, we were operating 863 tank barges. That compares to the beginning of the year when we had 914 barges operating. The tank barge industry still has excess capacity. We've noted that throughout last year. The strong demand experienced in the previous years encouraged the industry to build new equipment, but also to keep older equipment in service to meet higher demand levels. In early 2008, the industry was fully utilized and shipyards were fully booked through 2008 and 2009. Approximately 180 to 200 tank barges were delivered last year in an environment of falling demand. These were barges that were ordered in the 2007-early 2008 timeframe. These new barges have further increased industry capacity and have contributed to the pressure of term and spot contract rates. However, as we've indicated before, the industry's overcapacity problem, in our view, should be a short-lived problem. Because over 500 barges in the industry fleet are over 35 years old, and approximately 250 of those are actually over 40 years old. All inland tank barges must pass Coast Guard inspections, and older barges typically cost more to maintain and are likely to be retired at an accelerated pace in a weak market. That's what Kirby did last year and will continue to do this year unless the market improves appreciably.During the fourth quarter -- this is turning to our Diesel Engine business. Our Diesel Engine Service segment demand levels for service and direct parts remained under stress, as both our medium-speed and high-speed offshore service customers, as well as our Marine Transportation customers and real customers deferred maintenance and idled equipment in response to lower utilization. We're able to partially offset these weak markets by continuing to take operating cost out of the business. Medium-speed Power Generation market was stable for most of the year. We think that, again, we're close to the bottom, if not on the bottom, in this business and anticipate some improvement latter part of 2010.On January 23 this year, Kirby was involved in an incident in the Port Arthur area which resulted in a spill that closed the gulf and that closed the waterway. This was a collision between a ship and one of our tows. We do not believe that we're at fault here. This has not, however, stop movement of a number of tows as well as some ships. Over 40 tows that Kirby operates were affected and about 30 ships were also affected. These tows and ships are beginning to move again. The cost to Kirby at this point is unknown and will depend on when the waterway is returned to full operation, the mix of tows that we have involved with respect to time charters versus freightment and the effect of any pent-up demand, which is really unclear at this point. We do think that over the next couple of weeks, it'll be clear. I'll come back at the end of this call and talk about 2010. But let me now turn the call over to Norman.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. As we discussed in our press release, we had three adjustments, two of which had a negative impact and one, a positive impact on our 2009 fourth quarter and year end. The first negative adjustment was a $4.8 million pretax charge for reducti
componenttext: Good morning. As we discussed in our press release, we had three adjustments, two of which had a negative impact and one, a positive impact on our 2009 fourth quarter and year end. The first negative adjustment was a $4.8 million pretax charge for reductions in our Marine Transportation, Diesel Engine Services and corporate shore staff personnel. These actions were taken to enable us to remain competitive in the Marine Transportation and Diesel Engine Services markets and to better position the company to weather this continuing economic downturn. The second negative adjustment was a $1.9 million charge for the partial impairment of Osprey Lines goodwill. Osprey had a two-thirds-owned cargo container and private cargo inland waterways operator. The impairment of Osprey's goodwill reflected current market conditions, not the abandonment of this market. We continue to believe that the water transportation of containers is part of the answer to highway and railroad congestion and positive for the environment. But the recent focus has been on the more profitable Project Cargo business. The positive adjustment for the fourth quarter was a $2 million net reduction in our allowance for doubtful accounts. Last year in the fourth quarter, we increased our allowance by $6 million, the result of deteriorating U.S. and global economic environment and the impact the recession was having on several of our customers in the petrochemical industry. The $2 million reduction of the allowance this year reflects the improvement in the financial health and creditworthiness of these same customers as they weather the economic downturn. Although Kirby's Marine Transportation operating income was 18% below the 2008 fourth quarter, the operating margin of 23.6%, was in line with the 2008 fourth quarter of 23.4%. And if you adjust for the staff reduction charge and the positive impact of the reduction in the allowance for doubtful accounts, our 2009 fourth quarter margin was 24%. The higher margin resulted in the impact of lower fuel prices, the first quarter staff reductions, fewer charter boats, reduced maintenance on laid-up equipment, ongoing cost reduction and efficiency initiatives and more efficient operations. The Diesel Engine Services operating income and operating margin was lower than last year and the corresponding quarter. Adjusted for the staff reduction charge and a $500,000 increase in Diesel's allowance for doubtful accounts, the fourth quarter margin was 12.2%. Continued customer deferral of the Diesel Engine Maintenance project resulted in lower labor utilization in most areas, but especially in the domestic offshore oil services market. We had another very strong cash flow quarter with EBITDA of $74 million. At December 31, we had $98 million of cash and cash equivalents. As of yesterday, our cash voucher's $140 million, and we had no outstanding balance on our $250 million revolving credit facility. Our capital spending for 2009 totaled $193 million, which included $142 million for new tank barges and towboats. Our capital spending guidance for 2010 is a range of $125 million to $135 million, which includes approximately $60 million for new tank barge and towboat construction which Berdon will discuss. I'll now turn the call over to Berdon.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Norman. During 2009, we took delivery of 43 new barges and seven new charter barges with a total capacity of 1.1 million barrels. We also took delivery in 2009 of four 1,800-horsepower towboats, three 10,000-barrel barges, three 30,000-barrel b
componenttext: Thank you, Norman. During 2009, we took delivery of 43 new barges and seven new charter barges with a total capacity of 1.1 million barrels. We also took delivery in 2009 of four 1,800-horsepower towboats, three 10,000-barrel barges, three 30,000-barrel barges and three 1,800-horsepower towboats have been placed into early 2010 for delivery. Based on current market conditions and fleet utilization, as Joe stated earlier, we have accelerated the retirement schedule of some of our older, active tank barges. As of December 31, we owned or operated 863 active tank barges with a capacity of 16.7 million barrels. This compares with 914 tank barges owned and operated as of December 31, 2008, with a capacity of 17.5 million barrels. For 2010, to take advantage of attractive barge constructive prices and to continue to upgrade our fleet and to provide our customers new equipment to move their cargos, we contracted for the construction of 50 10,000-barrel and five 30,000-barrel tank barges, all for delivery in 2010. Based on current economic conditions, we are forecasting that at the end of 2010, our barge count and capacity will decline slightly, as we continue to remove older barges from the fleet. I will now turn the call back over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Berdon. Our 2010 first quarter guidance is $0.42 to $0.47, compared with $0.52 per share earned in the 2009 first quarter. This guidance also includes an estimated $0.04 per share first quarter 2010 charge for further staff reductions, which we
componenttext: Thank you, Berdon. Our 2010 first quarter guidance is $0.42 to $0.47, compared with $0.52 per share earned in the 2009 first quarter. This guidance also includes an estimated $0.04 per share first quarter 2010 charge for further staff reductions, which were implemented in early January this year. Since our peak headcount in October of 2008, which was about the beginning of this recession, through early retirements, staff reductions accretion, we've reduced our company-wide short staff by 21%. We've also taken a number of other cost out of our business including a significant reduction in the number of charter boats we're operating from a high of 104 beginning in 2008 to where it is today, 61.  A number of boats have come out of our business model. We've also laid up the company-owned boats. We've reduced maintenance on laid-up equipment, as well as our other ongoing cost-reduction initiatives. We've also reduced our barge fleet by 51 barges. Our 2010 guidance of $1.85 to $2.20 per share is what we published yesterday. Frankly, this is based on our best information as of today. As we know more, we'll continue to confirm or update our estimates. We've debated whether it's prudent even to give guidance included that we're closer to our business than our investors. And we think that there's some benefit of sharing with you what we think as of today. Our Marine Transportation and Diesel Engine Service markets remain under pressure. However, we do believe that we're close to the bottom, as I said earlier and in the Engine business and in the Marine Transportation business. The question is, when are the markets going to recover? Barging rates were under pressure throughout last year, and we do believe that they remain under pressure until at least mid-2010. To achieve pricing power, barge capacity will need to be removed from the industry fleet or volumes will need to improve to absorb the existing capacity. I suspect that we'll see some of both later this year. So here we are at 2010. Although we'd like to be forecasting better earnings, it is what it is. Kirby is in excellent shape, however. We've taken a significant amount of cost out of our business. We have a strong balance sheet, low debt levels at favorable interest rates and cash on our balance sheet, which will continue to build throughout the year. Norman told you, as of yesterday, we have $114 million of cash on our balance sheet. Industry stress and the current economic environment aren't necessarily bad for Kirby long term. Our businesses will recover, stress creates opportunities to grow either through acquisition or through internal growth opportunities. It allows us to take advantage of favorable shipyard pricing and should encourage the industry to reduce barge capacity. Earlier this month, we filed an 8-K announcing Norman's retirement at the end of the first quarter. Norman's been Kirby's CFO since February of 1999 and has helped [indiscernible] the company through a number of acquisitions as well as Sarbanes-Oxley.  We noted on our press release that we've hired David Grzebinski to replace Norman as Kirby's CFO. David brings with him a lot of experience, and I look forward to working with David as we continue to manage Kirby and create value for shareholders. And we're going to miss Norman. Norman has been a friend and a partner. He's been a superb CFO. He has agreed to continue to be involved with Kirby on a consulting basis available to the management team at Kirby's Board at least through April of 2011. We also announced yesterday the appointment of Renato Castro as the Treasurer for Kirby. Now operator, I think we'll now open the call up for questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Natasha Boyden from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Natasha Boyden from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: With only $130 million in anticipated CapEx for '10, and you've obviously got road to the low-leverage levels, how do you look the use of cash flow going forward? And where do you see the most fastest growth either in the Marine Transportation sector or D
componenttext: With only $130 million in anticipated CapEx for '10, and you've obviously got road to the low-leverage levels, how do you look the use of cash flow going forward? And where do you see the most fastest growth either in the Marine Transportation sector or Diesel Engine Services?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to be patient with the use of our cash, looking for opportunities both acquisition, make a sort of building some additional equipment stock repurchases. In terms of where we think the best growth opportunity is, it's hard to say. But it'
componenttext: Well, we're going to be patient with the use of our cash, looking for opportunities both acquisition, make a sort of building some additional equipment stock repurchases. In terms of where we think the best growth opportunity is, it's hard to say. But it's probably now in the Marine Transportation area.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and would you be looking at more on an M&A-basis buying fleet or would you be looking to grow more organically though?
componenttext: Okay, and would you be looking at more on an M&A-basis buying fleet or would you be looking to grow more organically though?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Both. But we think that this is a good environment for consolidation. And I think that consolidation, regardless of whether we do it or somebody else does it, it's going to be healthy for the business long term.
componenttext: Both. But we think that this is a good environment for consolidation. And I think that consolidation, regardless of whether we do it or somebody else does it, it's going to be healthy for the business long term.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The Diesel Engine Services segment obviously have an impact to the customer-deferred maintenance. Generally, how long can that maintenance be deferred? And could we expect to rebound later in 2010?
componenttext: The Diesel Engine Services segment obviously have an impact to the customer-deferred maintenance. Generally, how long can that maintenance be deferred? And could we expect to rebound later in 2010?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think that impact, that's likely to happen.
componenttext: Yes, we think that impact, that's likely to happen.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so the maintenance can't be deferred?
componenttext: Okay, so the maintenance can't be deferred?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: There's a limit to it. What happens, Natasha, is that the utilization declines. The customer will tie up equipment. They tie the equipment up that is the most expensive to operate, equipment that needs maintenance, typically. At some point, you run out of
componenttext: There's a limit to it. What happens, Natasha, is that the utilization declines. The customer will tie up equipment. They tie the equipment up that is the most expensive to operate, equipment that needs maintenance, typically. At some point, you run out of equipment to tie up, and then you have to do the maintenance. We think that we're certainly closer to that today than we were at the beginning of last year.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Sterling from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Sterling from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, you talked about capacity reductions for your fleet in '09, and sounds like in 2010, is that the plan -- are you planning to shrink your fleet this year? If so, do you have an idea of how much?
componenttext: Joe, you talked about capacity reductions for your fleet in '09, and sounds like in 2010, is that the plan -- are you planning to shrink your fleet this year? If so, do you have an idea of how much?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not saying how much. But at least, based on current market conditions, the fleet will be smaller at the end of 2010 than it is today. But it needs to be just Kirby. I mean you need to see capacity come out of the industry in general.
componenttext: We're not saying how much. But at least, based on current market conditions, the fleet will be smaller at the end of 2010 than it is today. But it needs to be just Kirby. I mean you need to see capacity come out of the industry in general.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Right, and it sounds like we may see industry reduction particularly maybe by the back half of this year?
componenttext: Right, and it sounds like we may see industry reduction particularly maybe by the back half of this year?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It's what we hope so.
componenttext: It's what we hope so.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: About acquisitions, you mentioned there's some opportunities out there particularly on the Marine Transportation side. Are valuations still too high in your opinion? Or they started to come in some?
componenttext: About acquisitions, you mentioned there's some opportunities out there particularly on the Marine Transportation side. Are valuations still too high in your opinion? Or they started to come in some?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I really don't want to comment on that yet. I think that it would be premature to comment, Kevin.
componenttext: Well, I really don't want to comment on that yet. I think that it would be premature to comment, Kevin.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, as you retire older barges, what's the average age of your fleet now?
componenttext: Joe, as you retire older barges, what's the average age of your fleet now?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It continues to move down. It's probably down a year, a year and a half. And if you take the pressure in anhydrous ammonia equipment out, those tanks will last theoretically forever in which typically to is build new holes around the tanks. The fleet aver
componenttext: It continues to move down. It's probably down a year, a year and a half. And if you take the pressure in anhydrous ammonia equipment out, those tanks will last theoretically forever in which typically to is build new holes around the tanks. The fleet average is under 20 years.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And some of the contracts that are rolling over this year that need to be repriced, about how many of those are two and three-year old contracts? Or most of your contracts rolling over one year in nature?
componenttext: And some of the contracts that are rolling over this year that need to be repriced, about how many of those are two and three-year old contracts? Or most of your contracts rolling over one year in nature?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: For the most part, they're one year in nature. And they're going to represent this year about 25% of our revenue. So then, combined with the spot, you're going to have about 50% of the revenue exposed to repricing in 2010.
componenttext: For the most part, they're one year in nature. And they're going to represent this year about 25% of our revenue. So then, combined with the spot, you're going to have about 50% of the revenue exposed to repricing in 2010.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Is most of that repricing in first half of the year, or the second part of the year, or is it hard to tell?
componenttext: Is most of that repricing in first half of the year, or the second part of the year, or is it hard to tell?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Of course, spot pricing is on a day-to-day basis. But the contracts are pretty ratable throughout the year.
componenttext: Of course, spot pricing is on a day-to-day basis. But the contracts are pretty ratable throughout the year.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you talk your customers, what are they saying about the current environment? How do they feel about 2010?
componenttext: As you talk your customers, what are they saying about the current environment? How do they feel about 2010?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it depends on the customer, of course. But I think the customers are maybe a little more optimistic about their business. But remember that the Barge business is a supply and demand business. You can have disconnects between where your custo
componenttext: Well, I think it depends on the customer, of course. But I think the customers are maybe a little more optimistic about their business. But remember that the Barge business is a supply and demand business. You can have disconnects between where your customer is and where you are. But I think generally, they see their business continuing to strengthen in 2010. We'll have a better feel for that because we're all announcing their earnings for the next couple of weeks, and they'll be talking about 2010. But in the private discussions we had, we sensed that they feel a little better about 2010.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Barnes from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Barnes from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, can you talk a little bit about this potential increase in exposure to the spot market? I think you've talked a number of times about that exposure ebbing from kind of the 20% spot in 2009 to maybe more like 30% spot in 2010. Can you just talk a litt
componenttext: Joe, can you talk a little bit about this potential increase in exposure to the spot market? I think you've talked a number of times about that exposure ebbing from kind of the 20% spot in 2009 to maybe more like 30% spot in 2010. Can you just talk a little bit about it? I guess I'm trying to figure out, it's not a bad thing. Obviously, you're feeling at right now, but it's that a bad thing longer term?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We think that we'll probably go back to the historical mix, which is 70%, 30%. We'll trend towards a higher exposure to Spot business than we have now. It's good and bad. In a falling market, of course, it means that you're exposed more to spot rates, whi
componenttext: We think that we'll probably go back to the historical mix, which is 70%, 30%. We'll trend towards a higher exposure to Spot business than we have now. It's good and bad. In a falling market, of course, it means that you're exposed more to spot rates, which typically leap contract rates in a negative way. They're typically lower than contract rates. It's positive because our systems and sales team and operating team really can accommodate the flexibility and respond to spot market opportunities as well as anybody in the business. So we're in a very good position to capture Spot business, and hold utilization rates may be better than certainly some of our competitors can. We've always maintained an element of our business that spot where some competitors are more contract based. They'll try to have 100% of their business, particularly smaller Canal operators in Contract business so they don't have to worry about booking a tow on a day-to-day basis. I guess the long answer is it's good and bad.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about -- and I know you don't want to be too specific but, can you kind of talk about the progression of your scrapping plans? Is it more heavily weighted to the front end, to the back end? And what's influencing the timing of yo
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about -- and I know you don't want to be too specific but, can you kind of talk about the progression of your scrapping plans? Is it more heavily weighted to the front end, to the back end? And what's influencing the timing of your scrappage?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just make one other point on your previous question, John. Where it gets favorable of course is, when the market turns and spot prices start trending up, and then you have a higher spot exposure. That's a positive thing. With respect to scrapping,
componenttext: Let me just make one other point on your previous question, John. Where it gets favorable of course is, when the market turns and spot prices start trending up, and then you have a higher spot exposure. That's a positive thing. With respect to scrapping, it's going to be managed around maintenance decisions that we have to make on barges. So as barges come in and the maintenance needs to be extended to that barge, we'll make the decision whether to go ahead and maintain it or to get rid of it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The late tows you talked about as a result of the accident, is that permanently lost business? Or does that commodity just backup until you can eventually haul it?
componenttext: The late tows you talked about as a result of the accident, is that permanently lost business? Or does that commodity just backup until you can eventually haul it?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we should still move it. In a tighter market, it tends to be more positive because it stresses the -- well, it raises the utilization of the barge fleet and typically, you see higher rates projected in the spot market. With an industry fleet that's o
componenttext: Yes, we should still move it. In a tighter market, it tends to be more positive because it stresses the -- well, it raises the utilization of the barge fleet and typically, you see higher rates projected in the spot market. With an industry fleet that's operating at utilization levels that its currently operating at, I'm not sure we're going to see that this year. But at the same time, I don't think that the business is going to go away. Those volumes would be moved.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, between ACLI's exiting kind of the Houston office and maybe retrenching a little bit out of the liquid market, I'm not sure what they signal to the market. That's kind of the take we took. And then some of the other players maybe don't ha
componenttext: And then lastly, between ACLI's exiting kind of the Houston office and maybe retrenching a little bit out of the liquid market, I'm not sure what they signal to the market. That's kind of the take we took. And then some of the other players maybe don't have the capital to kind of reinvest in their fleets and that type of thing. Do you think there's more of a market share opportunity for you now than there has been in the past that maybe market shares have kind of stabilized over the last several years and now, there's more market share opportunity for Kirby just kind of from a pure organic standpoint not without having to acquire somebody or that type of thing?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As equipment exits the industry fleet at some point, as volumes come back, there should be a market share opportunity. But for now, I think that what you're seeing is everybody protecting their business. So nobody gives their business up easily, and a lot
componenttext: As equipment exits the industry fleet at some point, as volumes come back, there should be a market share opportunity. But for now, I think that what you're seeing is everybody protecting their business. So nobody gives their business up easily, and a lot of the rate pressure is just based on people protecting the business that they have. I think long term, that may indeed be the case. I would not look for that to happen short term.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jimmy Gibert from Rice Voelker.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jimmy Gibert from Rice Voelker.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And you're asked earlier, I guess, on the call about acquisitions, but lately, I've been hearing about some very tight financial situations at some pretty sizable competitors. And is that sort of progresses -- do you think that might loosen things up a bi
componenttext: And you're asked earlier, I guess, on the call about acquisitions, but lately, I've been hearing about some very tight financial situations at some pretty sizable competitors. And is that sort of progresses -- do you think that might loosen things up a bit? I mean, I know these guys are -- they're out protecting their business, as you say. But at some point, it seems like some of these guys might become available?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it'd be inappropriate for us to and I know you understand this, Jimmy, to comment on that. You hear lots of rumors, and it's just the environment that we're in and having gone through this before, a lot of that is overblown and overstated. P
componenttext: Well, I think it'd be inappropriate for us to and I know you understand this, Jimmy, to comment on that. You hear lots of rumors, and it's just the environment that we're in and having gone through this before, a lot of that is overblown and overstated. People tend to believe the worst. But having said that, we do think that the environment is good for consolidation. We certainly have a very strong balance sheet, and we have an objective to continue to grow our business. So we're looking for opportunities and then hopefully, we're going to see them.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And also, we're all hearing a couple of weeks back about some unusually icy conditions as far south as St. Louis, locks having trouble operating. And if you could just talk about that, I guess it's unusual versus the last couple of years, but is it really
componenttext: And also, we're all hearing a couple of weeks back about some unusually icy conditions as far south as St. Louis, locks having trouble operating. And if you could just talk about that, I guess it's unusual versus the last couple of years, but is it really that unusual? And has that had any effect on your operations at all?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, no. Certainly, in the late 70s through the 80s, we saw that routinely, much worse than we're seeing it today. My guess is it were -- these things cycle, and we're going to have some warm winters, we're going to have some cold winters. So we're seeing
componenttext: Oh, no. Certainly, in the late 70s through the 80s, we saw that routinely, much worse than we're seeing it today. My guess is it were -- these things cycle, and we're going to have some warm winters, we're going to have some cold winters. So we're seeing at least typically, well, a colder winter early on this year. Last year, at the same time, it was a cold winter then it warmed up. Currently, the temperature's a little warmer up there, and the ice is clearing. The conditions are pretty good. Couple of weeks ago, they were not so good.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then with regards to the Port Arthur collision, maybe you can or cannot comment, but I mean, I was told that the larger tank uphold in front of your tow. So it appear to be, if you will, the other guys' fault. And also did you guys didn't lose any car
componenttext: And then with regards to the Port Arthur collision, maybe you can or cannot comment, but I mean, I was told that the larger tank uphold in front of your tow. So it appear to be, if you will, the other guys' fault. And also did you guys didn't lose any cargo out of your equipment at all, is that right?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't lose any cargo, and we think you're right with respect to fault.
componenttext: We didn't lose any cargo, and we think you're right with respect to fault.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Yuschak from Madison Williams and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Yuschak from Madison Williams and Company.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Question I got for you, Joe, though, is you went from 80 to 75 in the fourth quarter on your contracts. Did you have a lot of run-off there that forced it there and what kind of time horizon as you look at some of your contracts? Do you think if you were
componenttext: Question I got for you, Joe, though, is you went from 80 to 75 in the fourth quarter on your contracts. Did you have a lot of run-off there that forced it there and what kind of time horizon as you look at some of your contracts? Do you think if you were to get to 70, you would get to 70?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to answer the latter part of your question, it's going to be sometime this year, we think. We had indicated, actually I think in the last call, that we thought that as the time charters rolled-off, that you'd see more of that equipment in the spot m
componenttext: Well, to answer the latter part of your question, it's going to be sometime this year, we think. We had indicated, actually I think in the last call, that we thought that as the time charters rolled-off, that you'd see more of that equipment in the spot market. And that's pretty much what's happened. Our time charter mix is down, and our spot exposure is up.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And probably if anything, maybe the first half of the year rather than the second half, do you think?
componenttext: And probably if anything, maybe the first half of the year rather than the second half, do you think?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: David, I don't want to predict that. I think it's going to happen throughout the year. I say something, it happens in the first quarter, and we're going to reach [ph]. I think it's going to happen, I'm just not sure that I can say when.
componenttext: David, I don't want to predict that. I think it's going to happen throughout the year. I say something, it happens in the first quarter, and we're going to reach [ph]. I think it's going to happen, I'm just not sure that I can say when.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you look at the -- with the capital spending you're doing this year, it would kind of suggest then that 2011, your capital spending could really drop off just because of having some comfort level to the age of the fleet that you have in existence at th
componenttext: As you look at the -- with the capital spending you're doing this year, it would kind of suggest then that 2011, your capital spending could really drop off just because of having some comfort level to the age of the fleet that you have in existence at that time? Is that fair to say, too?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. Some of it will depend on whether shipyard prices remain as attractive as they are now. And I'm not saying that even if they do, that we'll necessarily build, but that certainly will be a factor. This year, we're also going to build a
componenttext: I think that's fair. Some of it will depend on whether shipyard prices remain as attractive as they are now. And I'm not saying that even if they do, that we'll necessarily build, but that certainly will be a factor. This year, we're also going to build a gas-freeing facility in the Houston area, which we think will help us control costs and assure that the emissions that come out of our barges are handled appropriately. So some of the capital expenditure is building that facility, which we'll be through with in 2010. But we have the ability to really short term, and short term I mean, one or two years, to turn off almost all of the capital spending and just produce an enormous amount of cash. We chose not to do that because long term, you have to invest, reinvest in your business. At least with respect to the current building, we think that the replacement barges that we're building or being built at attractive prices and will position us very well in the future.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you think about your balance sheet today, this will be my last question, it's as strong as it's been in probably a decade by now. So you've ample capacity -- as you look at opportunity done, now whether they're in diesel or in consolidating the industr
componenttext: As you think about your balance sheet today, this will be my last question, it's as strong as it's been in probably a decade by now. So you've ample capacity -- as you look at opportunity done, now whether they're in diesel or in consolidating the industry, is it possible that, that kind of capacity could take you back to maybe some of the more historic ranges of debt to capital of 40%, 45% compared to the year of 15% today? Do you think you can use that much capital to pursue some of the opportunities you think that route there in both segments say, over the course of next 18 months to 24 months to get you there? Or would you in effect maybe be in even below that kind of a range?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Hard to say, David. It depends on the opportunity, of course. We hope so.
componenttext: Hard to say, David. It depends on the opportunity, of course. We hope so.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: But that's kind of where you -- ultimately, that target is at let's say, 45% debt-to-cap ratio, is that kind of ultimately leveraged?
componenttext: But that's kind of where you -- ultimately, that target is at let's say, 45% debt-to-cap ratio, is that kind of ultimately leveraged?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Around 40%, 45% is the optimum leverage for this business, given the cash flow characteristics of the business.
componenttext: Around 40%, 45% is the optimum leverage for this business, given the cash flow characteristics of the business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chaz Jones from Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chaz Jones from Morgan Keegan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I don't know if you or Berdon made the comment, but you mentioned about pushing delivery of some of the building that's going on. Was that your -- obviously, it was your decision. But are manufacturers coming to you and specifically asking you to pus
componenttext: Joe, I don't know if you or Berdon made the comment, but you mentioned about pushing delivery of some of the building that's going on. Was that your -- obviously, it was your decision. But are manufacturers coming to you and specifically asking you to push out delivery of equipment?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, that decision was made in kind of the middle of the financial crisis. And frankly, as we got more comfortable with our position, we encourage the shipyards to deliver on schedule. But because we had delayed some of the barges, that did push some into
componenttext: No, that decision was made in kind of the middle of the financial crisis. And frankly, as we got more comfortable with our position, we encourage the shipyards to deliver on schedule. But because we had delayed some of the barges, that did push some into 2010.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of contract negotiations, I know you talked about a lot about pricing on the call. But one thing I was curious about, are shippers or customers trying to negotiate longer-term contracts at the bottom of the market?
componenttext: In terms of contract negotiations, I know you talked about a lot about pricing on the call. But one thing I was curious about, are shippers or customers trying to negotiate longer-term contracts at the bottom of the market?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing a lot of that.
componenttext: We're not seeing a lot of that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then last one, some talk I guess on just the industry hub about raising the diesel tax to help subsidize the waterway improvement, just curious, in terms of if that were to happen, is that an added cost you can push onto the customer base?
componenttext: And then last one, some talk I guess on just the industry hub about raising the diesel tax to help subsidize the waterway improvement, just curious, in terms of if that were to happen, is that an added cost you can push onto the customer base?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, all our contracts have had the ability to pass that up.
componenttext: Yes, all our contracts have had the ability to pass that up.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve O'Hara from Sidoti & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve O'Hara from Sidoti & Company.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping if you could give a little commentary on in terms of your market share in the industry, are you seeing capacity come out kind of at the same rate as what you guys are taking out and if that's affecting your position going forward?
componenttext: I was hoping if you could give a little commentary on in terms of your market share in the industry, are you seeing capacity come out kind of at the same rate as what you guys are taking out and if that's affecting your position going forward?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we actually don't know. There is an industry survey that is done by enformo [ph] that should come out next month that'll give us a better indication of what was taken out. The challenge in 2009, of course, is you added somewhere between 180 to 200 ne
componenttext: Yes, we actually don't know. There is an industry survey that is done by enformo [ph] that should come out next month that'll give us a better indication of what was taken out. The challenge in 2009, of course, is you added somewhere between 180 to 200 new barges and did that many older barges go out? I don't know. I mean, we know that 101 came out because 101 were ours. But we don't know what other people have done at least at this point.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, I know you adjust those numbers that's why I thought you'd know.
componenttext: I mean, I know you adjust those numbers that's why I thought you'd know.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, one of the better feel is another month.
componenttext: Yes, well, one of the better feel is another month.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the various categories that you guys carry, I mean, are you seeing any strength or weakness in any of those? Is one better than the other or are they just kind of -- it's just capacity the issue really?
componenttext: And then in terms of the various categories that you guys carry, I mean, are you seeing any strength or weakness in any of those? Is one better than the other or are they just kind of -- it's just capacity the issue really?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, capacity is certainly an issue and the major issue. I would say that fertilizer in 2009, that's a relatively small part of what we do was down, and that we anticipate that it's going to be better in 2010. With respect to Black Oil and chemical volum
componenttext: Well, capacity is certainly an issue and the major issue. I would say that fertilizer in 2009, that's a relatively small part of what we do was down, and that we anticipate that it's going to be better in 2010. With respect to Black Oil and chemical volumes, chemical volumes have been stable, pretty much so for the last six months, they were down a little bit in the fourth quarter. And we think that, that was more fine tuning the inventories that our customers maintain. And that was also reflected in rail car loadings of chemicals, they were down quarter-over-quarter slightly. As we go into 2010, we just sensed that maybe the market's a little stronger. But you have to be careful because if you measure it by utilization, utilization's always weather-impacted. So we'll just have to see. And we have said that our customers are generally a little more optimistic about their performance in 2010 than we are.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess just one last question. In terms of the type of environment that you're in and what I guess you'd hope for, I mean, would you rather have a weaker environment in the near term to flush out some of that capacity and maybe just kind of hang
componenttext: And then I guess just one last question. In terms of the type of environment that you're in and what I guess you'd hope for, I mean, would you rather have a weaker environment in the near term to flush out some of that capacity and maybe just kind of hanging around, I mean, given your balance sheet and your cash flow? Or do you think that if you had a quick rebound, not that you're expecting that, but if you did, maybe some of that capacity might hang around longer than it should?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Having a difficult 2010 isn't all bad. I think you do encourage a fleet reduction, older equipment coming out. I think you encourage consolidation. Kirby's in great shape. Our earnings are down, but it's still -- even at $1.85, it is still a pretty good y
componenttext: Having a difficult 2010 isn't all bad. I think you do encourage a fleet reduction, older equipment coming out. I think you encourage consolidation. Kirby's in great shape. Our earnings are down, but it's still -- even at $1.85, it is still a pretty good year. And we will produce a lot of cash, and we'll continue to add cash to the balance sheet and a more difficult year should spring lose some opportunities.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Hoexter from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Hoexter from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Wilson Chen, speaking for Ken. I had a question in regards to the eventual rebound that we might see whether that'd be later this year or early next year, in terms of the cost that you guys have taken out, you spent at least -- on my coun
componenttext: This is actually Wilson Chen, speaking for Ken. I had a question in regards to the eventual rebound that we might see whether that'd be later this year or early next year, in terms of the cost that you guys have taken out, you spent at least -- on my count at least, two quarters backing out of expenses for reducing headcount. When volume does rebound, how much of these costs on a percentage basis do you think are going to be permanent, and what's going to be variable?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The boat cost will come back as volumes improve. But hopefully, margins will support, if they do come back, profits. With respect to the short staff headcount, we're sizing the company for lower volumes of a smaller fleet. And we should be able to handle
componenttext: The boat cost will come back as volumes improve. But hopefully, margins will support, if they do come back, profits. With respect to the short staff headcount, we're sizing the company for lower volumes of a smaller fleet. And we should be able to handle the volumes that our fleet can handle with the short staff that we have. So a lot of that should go away or remain going away. If we start growing again, then, of course, you're going to have to add short staff to accommodate that.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, like if I were to peg a number to for like a 10% increase in volume perhaps, how much short staff do you think you would have to bring back to accommodate that? Or would that just be incrementally kind of built into the structure already?
componenttext: Sure, like if I were to peg a number to for like a 10% increase in volume perhaps, how much short staff do you think you would have to bring back to accommodate that? Or would that just be incrementally kind of built into the structure already?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think a 5% to 10% increase could be handled with the current staff. I don't think you have to add a lot of staff to do that. The number, with respect to short staff headcount, if you look at kind of where we were as we went into this October 2008 t
componenttext: Yes, I think a 5% to 10% increase could be handled with the current staff. I don't think you have to add a lot of staff to do that. The number, with respect to short staff headcount, if you look at kind of where we were as we went into this October 2008 through higher increases and headcount reductions, intended headcount reductions, we've taken a little more than $27 million of cost there.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess my final question is kind of riding on that, just seeing that rebound eventually, as you made it very clear that spot rates will probably go back up along with rebound, I'm just curious as to whether you're seeing any of your legacy contractua
componenttext: And I guess my final question is kind of riding on that, just seeing that rebound eventually, as you made it very clear that spot rates will probably go back up along with rebound, I'm just curious as to whether you're seeing any of your legacy contractual customers not renewing in favor of the spot market because they do sense the fact that right now, it's great, but when the table is tilted the other way, it'll be a little bit harder for them. So I'm just wondering if you've seen any of that type of mentality or just thought process come through when you've spoken to your client?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we've certainly seen customers release chartered equipment and go out into the spot market to get their requirements filled. What we haven't seen are customers that are in the spot market time-chartering. And if we saw that, that would be posit
componenttext: Yes, well, we've certainly seen customers release chartered equipment and go out into the spot market to get their requirements filled. What we haven't seen are customers that are in the spot market time-chartering. And if we saw that, that would be positive.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Daniel Burke from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Burke from Johnson Rice.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions left. Well, first of all, with regard to the scrapping in the fleet, I was curious if you're conducting any scrapping within the aforementioned pressure and Black Oil fleet and I guess I was going to ask a question that kind of inquire into
componenttext: Two questions left. Well, first of all, with regard to the scrapping in the fleet, I was curious if you're conducting any scrapping within the aforementioned pressure and Black Oil fleet and I guess I was going to ask a question that kind of inquire into the health of those two sort of most specific markets?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Black Oil, yes. Pressure, we've replaced a barge or two, but it hasn't been significant. But in the Black Oil business, yes. We've taken a number of barges out.
componenttext: Black Oil, yes. Pressure, we've replaced a barge or two, but it hasn't been significant. But in the Black Oil business, yes. We've taken a number of barges out.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, two other questions and in a way they're implicit, since we've got the guidance for 2010. But I was curious on the evergreen contracts, I think you typically get for the multi-year contracts sort of an annual escalator, it's a little bit PPI-tie
componenttext: And then, two other questions and in a way they're implicit, since we've got the guidance for 2010. But I was curious on the evergreen contracts, I think you typically get for the multi-year contracts sort of an annual escalator, it's a little bit PPI-tied. I was wondering if you could quantify what you're in line for here in 2010? And then the second question, was I thought Dixie Offshore had a couple of contracts coming up this year for renewal and wanted to confirm those were expected to be extended?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, those contracts have been extended. With respect to multi-year contracts, did you talk about that? I'm not sure you did. Typically, what you see is -- if they're adjusted for PPI or CPI. Last year for example, last year being end of 2008 beginning of
componenttext: Yes, those contracts have been extended. With respect to multi-year contracts, did you talk about that? I'm not sure you did. Typically, what you see is -- if they're adjusted for PPI or CPI. Last year for example, last year being end of 2008 beginning of 2009, that timeframe, we saw adjustments on our multi-year contracts in the 4% to 5% range. This year, something that isn't supposed to happen because, of course, all contracts should be adjusted up. PPI was actually negative, and it works both ways. If it's positive, you get it, if it's negative, you'll lose it. Now CPI, which also adjusts some of the contracts that we operate under, was slightly positive. The two actually offset each other. So we got as we adjusted in January those multi-year contracts, 0%, where we typically get somewhere between 3% and 5%. Does that answer your question?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I guess that's what we sort of suspected. And just to clarify, that's more of the 20% of the revenue base, right?
componenttext: Yes, and I guess that's what we sort of suspected. And just to clarify, that's more of the 20% of the revenue base, right?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think it's close to 30%. Well that's about 30% of the contract base. And of course, contracts are about 75% of the business. So you have to do the math, but it's 25% or something of the revenue.
componenttext: Yes, we think it's close to 30%. Well that's about 30% of the contract base. And of course, contracts are about 75% of the business. So you have to do the math, but it's 25% or something of the revenue.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Larkin from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Larkin from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the accident that occurred recently and sort of the indication seems to be that the accident was caused by an error on the part of the person operating the ship in your vessel. At the end of the day, not being familiar with these sorts
componenttext: I had a question on the accident that occurred recently and sort of the indication seems to be that the accident was caused by an error on the part of the person operating the ship in your vessel. At the end of the day, not being familiar with these sorts of accidents, is fault really a factor determining who is financially responsible for the cleanup?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is, fault. It should be. This world is blessed with many lawyers with many points of view defending their clients vigorously. But we think as the facts roll out, it confirms what we initially thought and that is that the Kirby vessel was not at fa
componenttext: Yes, it is, fault. It should be. This world is blessed with many lawyers with many points of view defending their clients vigorously. But we think as the facts roll out, it confirms what we initially thought and that is that the Kirby vessel was not at fault. And in fact, they couldn't have done anything almost in any scenario to avoid colliding with the ship. Now having said that, we also carry $1 billion of insurance. So we're well-insured, even if it was our fault.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: What is the deductible on that?
componenttext: What is the deductible on that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It's $1 million, John. $1 million per incident.
componenttext: It's $1 million, John. $1 million per incident.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Up to, did I hear you say $1 billion cover?
componenttext: Up to, did I hear you say $1 billion cover?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: $1 billion, yes. $1 billion incur, if ever.
componenttext: $1 billion, yes. $1 billion incur, if ever.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the acquisition front, I guess, not to beat a dead horse here, but I've been sort of thinking that we might have seen one by now. Certainly, your balance sheet is in good enough shape to support one. What is your feeling about the type of acqu
componenttext: And then on the acquisition front, I guess, not to beat a dead horse here, but I've been sort of thinking that we might have seen one by now. Certainly, your balance sheet is in good enough shape to support one. What is your feeling about the type of acquisition that might be most likely here? Would it be perhaps the takeover of a customer's dedicated fleet? Or would it more likely be an independent operator that perhaps doesn't have the strongest balance sheet as a stand-alone entity?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'd take either. Hard say what's more likely. I do think that it's still a little early. If you remember, the business really didn't start coming under pressure until the first quarter of 2009. And we'll just have to see what 2010 yields. If it's go
componenttext: Yes, we'd take either. Hard say what's more likely. I do think that it's still a little early. If you remember, the business really didn't start coming under pressure until the first quarter of 2009. And we'll just have to see what 2010 yields. If it's going to be a difficult year, more stress is going to be put on, certainly, operators that are more levered than they'd like to be. The other thing to remember is that nobody likes to be acquired even by nice people like us. So there's going to be some resistance. So nobody is going to be anxious to be purchased. So we just need to let time settle what's going to happen.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finishing up on a topic that I think has been approached from about 40 different angles here, that being pricing, I guess my impression was and I guess this must have been incorrect, that Kirby had developed sufficient market share and enoug
componenttext: And then just finishing up on a topic that I think has been approached from about 40 different angles here, that being pricing, I guess my impression was and I guess this must have been incorrect, that Kirby had developed sufficient market share and enough, what I would call, strength in the marketplace that in many cases, the shippers were using you because you are financially stronger, safer, more time definite in your operation and a lower risk than somebody who may come along with a lower price. Yet, it seems like we're now basically in what I would call a free-running supply and demand-driven environment, where the guy with the lowest price kind of wins when the time charters expire. Has something changed? Or did I not fully understand the market properly in the first place?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it depends on the customer. You have some customers that are very aggressive right now with respect to price, using our competition to delever us down in some cases. But it's a tough market. They're taking advantage of it. We do think that our uti
componenttext: I think it depends on the customer. You have some customers that are very aggressive right now with respect to price, using our competition to delever us down in some cases. But it's a tough market. They're taking advantage of it. We do think that our utilization levels are a little above where the industry is for the most part. I don't want to comment on where we think pricing is because I think that, that just wouldn't be to our advantage. But we do think that utilization's a little better.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Brand from Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Brand from Stephens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to follow up on that utilization question. If your time charters are down to 50% and those are effectively 100% utilization, and I assume that those are going to go down a little bit more as a percentage. How do you keep utilization in the low 80s?
componenttext: I want to follow up on that utilization question. If your time charters are down to 50% and those are effectively 100% utilization, and I assume that those are going to go down a little bit more as a percentage. How do you keep utilization in the low 80s? Or is there a downside to that utilization number?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me think about that. Yes because we do count time charters are fully utilized, you're right. Well, I don't think that time charters are going to get a lot worse. Most of that has rolled over. There are few that'll roll over kind of first part of
componenttext: Yes, let me think about that. Yes because we do count time charters are fully utilized, you're right. Well, I don't think that time charters are going to get a lot worse. Most of that has rolled over. There are few that'll roll over kind of first part of this year. But most of it's rolled over. I do think it's going to go down a little bit, but not a lot. Utilization, as we speak, is probably mid-80s. So it can slide a little bit and still be in that range, so hard to answer. I think net-net, though, that we'll see utilization probably in the 80% to 85% though this year. May lose some on the time charter area at the limes [ph] maybe a little better. But I don't think that utilization is going to be above 85% nor do I think it's going to be below 80% either.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And with respect to capacity in the market, how much overcapacity do you think there is? Do you still think it's in that sort of 10% range that you've mentioned before?
componenttext: And with respect to capacity in the market, how much overcapacity do you think there is? Do you still think it's in that sort of 10% range that you've mentioned before?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's somewhere between 300 and probably 400 barges. That's what's going to have to come out. And that's based on what I think the fleet is today. We took 100 barges out. That's a lot of barges. But we'll take a little more equipment out, but
componenttext: Yes, I think it's somewhere between 300 and probably 400 barges. That's what's going to have to come out. And that's based on what I think the fleet is today. We took 100 barges out. That's a lot of barges. But we'll take a little more equipment out, but the rest of the industry's going to need to take some equipment out also.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So in other words, that's your sort of best guess as to that many come out and pricing would certainly start to move up?
componenttext: So in other words, that's your sort of best guess as to that many come out and pricing would certainly start to move up?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, now that's assuming, Alex, stable volumes. As you get volume increases, that'll absorb some of that capacity. So if you got 5% of volume, that reduces the number of barges coming out. From a managing Kirby perspective, we are making our management de
componenttext: Yes, now that's assuming, Alex, stable volumes. As you get volume increases, that'll absorb some of that capacity. So if you got 5% of volume, that reduces the number of barges coming out. From a managing Kirby perspective, we are making our management decisions assuming that volumes are essentially flat.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: One more question, if I could. When you think about strategically what's going on in the market and your opportunity to use your near-record margins and your balance sheet, is this a time for you guys to think about market share? And I guess what I'm aski
componenttext: One more question, if I could. When you think about strategically what's going on in the market and your opportunity to use your near-record margins and your balance sheet, is this a time for you guys to think about market share? And I guess what I'm asking here is, how do you think about your strategic pricing? Are you willing to take share because now is the time to do that? And if you take so now at discounted prices, there's a bigger pay off down the road?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it depends on the business. I'm not saying that we're not willing to do it, but we won't take share at any price. But there is some business that is attractive, it fits. We'll get pretty aggressive on it.
componenttext: Yes, it depends on the business. I'm not saying that we're not willing to do it, but we won't take share at any price. But there is some business that is attractive, it fits. We'll get pretty aggressive on it.
