componenttext: Welcome to the Kirby Corporation First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Anthony, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the call over to your host, Steve Holcomb. Mr. Holcomb, you may begin.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation
componenttext: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under non-GAAP financial data. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's annual report on Form 10-K for the year-end December 31, 2009, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I will now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Late yesterday, we reported net earnings for the 2010 first quarter of $0.46 per share, compared with $0.52 per share reported for the 2009 first quarter. Included in our first quarter results was a previously announced $0.05 per share
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Late yesterday, we reported net earnings for the 2010 first quarter of $0.46 per share, compared with $0.52 per share reported for the 2009 first quarter. 
Included in our first quarter results was a previously announced $0.05 per share charge for retirements and shore staff reductions. Our 2009 first quarter results also included a $0.05 per charge for early retirements and shore staff reductions. 
Announced earnings guidance for the first quarter was $0.42 to $0.47 per share and included an estimated $0.04 per share costs for shore staff redundancies. The actual charge that we incurred in the first quarter was slightly higher, a $0.05 charge. 
During the 2010 first quarter, our Marine Transportation volumes improved, compared to both the 2009 first and fourth quarters. Our barge utilization for the first quarter, which is always impacted by weather, averaged in the mid-80s to high-80 range, above all four 2009 quarter levels and frankly, better than forecasted. 
In addition to increased petrochemical production, the improvement in our barge utilization level was also helped by some supply-chain disruptions caused by petrochemical and refraining plant turnarounds, as well as some unscheduled plant maintenance. Our higher volumes were also driven by improved demand for exported petrochemicals. 
U.S. petrochemical complex is enjoying a feedstock advantage today due to a relatively low natural gas costs in the U.S. compared to current crude oil prices. During the first quarter, the term contract portion of our revenue mix remained at about 75% contract, 25% spot. 
Our time charters represented a little less than 50% of total term contracts, compared to the 52% time charter mix we reported in the fourth quarter. While some customers have switched to spot freight in the contracts when their time charters have expired, others have just taken shorter charters of equipment as they're not ready to commit longer-term positions at this point. 
With improved volumes and resulting higher barge utilization rates during the first quarter, we did see pricing stabilize. Term contracts that were renewed during the first quarter generally decreased on average approximately 10% when compared with the term contracts that were renewed first quarter of 2009, with some firming in the contract areas as the quarter progressed. 
Spot contract rates for the first quarter, which of course include fuel and fuel was higher, were down 15% to 25% compared with first quarter spot pricing. But when compared to the fourth quarter, were up 3% to 6%. Again, this represents, I think, the stabilization of pricing in our business. 
With respect to the multi-year contracts that were typically renewed first of the year and escalated first of the year, these are contracts that don't expire in any given year. They're escalated for labor and either the producer price index or the consumer price index. The pricing was neutral for 2010. Typically in previous years, we've gotten anywhere from a 3% to 5% increase. 
The tank barge industry still has some excess capacity. Certainly, the demand that was experienced 2007, 2008, encouraged the industry to build new equipment. But also it encouraged the industry to keep older equipment and service, which typically would've been retired, to meet the higher demand levels. 
In 2009, 192 tank barges were delivered. We estimate about 140 barges were retired in 2009 for a net addition to the industry of about 50 barges. As of the beginning of 2010, we estimate there are approximately 3,150 tank barges in the industry, of which 500 are 35 years old and approximately 250 are 40 years old. 
For 2010, we believe that less than 100 barges will be constructed. Of those less than 100 barges, 58 are going to be ordered by Kirby. With respect to the barges that Kirby isn't building, a number of the barges being built in 2010 were in fact ordered for delivery in 2009 deferred into 2010. And the shipper is also building nine barges for his proprietary fleet serving his internal needs. 
Given the Asia profile of the industry fleet, we continue to expect older barges to be removed from service, and the industry supply versus demand will continue to move closer to balance. We're certainly encouraged by our improved utilization and the pricing stabilization that we're seeing. Demand is better as measured by the volumes that were moving. 
Certainly, demand is better than it was in 2009, and a little better than we thought it would be. However, we do expect our utilization to decline somewhat as weather improves and the supply chain becomes more efficient. This is not untypical in usual years, in late spring and in the summer, you typically see the industry utilization decline a little bit. 
The difference in 2007, 2008 was that there was so much demand that the industry was just fully utilized the entire year. During the 2010 first quarter, this is -- I'm talking about the Diesel Engine business, that segment demand levels for service and direct part sales generally remained weak across the majority of its markets, particularly, the high-speed oil service market. 
We did benefit from some first quarter seasonal work that we generally see in the Midwest and Great Lakes area for medium-speed marine customers. Our service customers continue to defer major maintenance, and this is in the oil service area. The medium-speed power generation market remained healthy, and our medium-speed railroad market benefited from improved direct part sales, as the utilization level for our railroad customers' equipment slowly improved, really reflecting improvements in demand for what they're producing. We do believe demand has bottomed out, but we still haven't seen any consistent signs of improvement in this business segment yet. I'll come back and talk more about this, as well as the outlook for the Inland Tank Barge business later in this call, but first, let me turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you Joe. As we disclosed in our press release, we continue to focus our attention on operating as prudently and as efficiently as possible. We did this by further reducing our cost in order to remain competitive as we try and
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you Joe. As we disclosed in our press release, we continue to focus our attention on operating as prudently and as efficiently as possible. We did this by further reducing our cost in order to remain competitive as we try and emerge from this economic downturn. 
In January 2010, we further reduced our Marine Transportation and corporate staffs through retirements and reductions, and we took a $4.1 million before-tax charge or $0.05 per share charge in the quarter. We took a similar early retirement and reduction charge in 2009 first quarter. Since our peak headcount in October 2008, we've reduced our shore staff headcount by 22% through early retirements, staff reductions and attritions. 
Kirby's Marine Transportation operating income was 8% below the 2009 first quarter and the operating margin of 19.3% was below the 2009 first quarter margin of 21%. Adjusting for the staff reduction charges in both quarters, the first quarter margin for this quarter would've been 20.5% compared with 22.3% for the first quarter in 2009. 
The lower margin reflected the impact of lower-term and spot-contract pricing throughout the last three quarters of 2009, some higher fuel prices and some more difficult operating conditions with weather and whatnot, partially offset by the benefit of the cost reductions from the headcount reductions that we initiated. The Diesel Engine Services operating income was in line with last year's first quarter. The operating margin was 10.4%. 
This compared with 8.7% reported for the 2009 first quarter or 11.1% adjusted for early retirements and staff reductions taken in the first quarter of 2009. Customers continue to defer their diesel engine maintenance projects, resulting in continued low labor utilization for the business. 
We have a strong cash flow generation quarter. EBITDA was $66 million in the quarter, and as of quarter end at March 31, we had $121 million in cash or in cash equivalents. Our capital spending for the first quarter totaled $34 million, which included $21 million for new tank barges and towboats and $13 million, primarily for capital upgrades to the existing fleet. 
Our capital spending guidance for 2010 remains in the range of $125 million to $135 million, which includes approximately $60 million for new tank barges and towboat construction. During the 2010 first quarter, we took delivery of 16 new 10,000-barrel and two 30,000-barrel tank barges, which added about 226,000 barrels of capacity. 
However, we also retired tank barges in the quarter, 20. And that reduced our overall capacity by 365,000 barrels. So net-net our capacity declined about 139,000 barrels during the quarter. As of March 31, we operated 861 tank barges with the total capacity of 16.6 million barrels. This compares with our peak tank barge count of 918 back in June 30 of 2008, and a peak capacity of about 17.5 million barrels. 
So this reflects a 6% reduction from the peak number of tank barges we operate and about a 5% reduction from our peak tank barge capacity. For the remainder of 2010, as we have stated before, to take advantage of attractive barge construction prices and to continue to upgrade our fleet and provide our customers with newer equipment, we will take delivery of 37 new 10,000-barrel barges, three 30,000-barrel barges and five new 10,000-barrel chartered barges, which will add about 530,000 barrels of capacity. 
However, we will continue to retire older tank barges from the fleets. So with that now, I'll turn it back to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. I'll turn to the outlook for the second quarter and the year. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our second quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share, which compares to $0.63 per share earned in the second quarter of last year. If you
componenttext:
Thank you, David. I'll turn to the outlook for the second quarter and the year. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our second quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share, which compares to $0.63 per share earned in the second quarter of last year. If you take the $0.46 per share, first quarter earnings, which reflected some modest improvement in volumes, add back the $0.05 per share staff reduction charge and look for some improvement in weather and operating conditions, you're basically at the low end of our range, the $0.52 level. 
The $0.57 high end of the range assumes that we continue to see Transportation volumes improve somewhat. We're forecasting for the Diesel Engine business kind of flat operating results, similar to other results in the first quarter. 
As for the full year, based on a more positive outlook for the balance of the year, we're raising our low-end guidance to $2, up from the $1.85 that we put out at the beginning of the year. And we're maintaining our high-end guidance of $2.20 per share. 
Our previous $1.85 low-end guidance assumed 2010 volumes would be consistent with volumes in 2009 and continued downward pressure on term contract renewals and spot contract pricing, at least, through the first half of the year. Fortunately, during the first quarter, volumes improved at contract and spot market pricing stabilized. And with respect to spot prices, we're, in fact, up a little. 
Therefore, the new $2 low-end guidance assumes volumes are going to be stable for the remainder of 2010, and that pricing is going to remain about where it is. Our $2.20 high-end guidance assumes continued modest improvement in volumes as the year progresses and a continued reduction in the current number of tank barges, a reduction in capacity. This all combining to lead to some modest improvement in term and spot pricing in the second half of the year. 
As we stated in last quarter's call, to achieve pricing power, barge capacity will need to be removed from the industry fleet where volumes will need to improve to absorb existing capacity or a combination of both will need to happen. We did see some improvement in volumes during the quarter. And time will tell whether, frankly, these volumes are sustainable. If they are sustainable, we suspect that we will see some modest pricing power in the second half of 2010. 
Now Kirby is in great financial shape. We've taken significant amount of cost out of our business last year, early this year. We have a very strong balance sheet, low level of debt, favorable interest rates and cash on our balance sheet that should continue to build. In March of this year, S&P increased our credit rating from a BBB+ to a investment grade rated A-. 
So we remain in excellent position to execute our objective of making strategic acquisitions as they become available. Also I want to comment, before we open the call up to questions, on -- for the retirement of Berdon Lawrence, Kirby's Chairman of the Board since 1999. 
Yesterday, Berdon retired. He has announced that he was going to retire on October of last year. I would like to thank Berdon, publicly, for his service not only to Kirby, but to the inland tank barge industry. He has truly been a leader of this industry and has helped guide Kirby to its success while serving as Kirby's Chairman. I have enjoyed working with Berdon over the past 10 years, beginning with the integration of Hollywood into Kirby and continuing over those years with Kirby's strategy of enhancing and growing our core businesses through synergistic acquisitions, and also creating enhanced earnings and value for our shareholders. 
Fortunately, Berdon is not going to go far. He is going to serve on Kirby's board. He's going to be Kirby's Chairman Emeritus and we'll still have access to his wisdom. Operator, I think we're now ready to open the call up for questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Alex [Alexander Brand] of Stephens.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Alex [Alexander Brand] of Stephens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is, help us understand, since I guess the beginning of '09, but when pricing turned down, what percentage of the contracts have been renewed and so that pricing down is behind us and what's still to come?
componenttext: My first question is, help us understand, since I guess the beginning of '09, but when pricing turned down, what percentage of the contracts have been renewed and so that pricing down is behind us and what's still to come?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As of today, probably about a third are behind us. But I think you have to -- I think a better way to look at this is that most of the pricing deterioration occurred in the first and second quarter. And then, it stabilized somewhere between, I think we sa
componenttext: As of today, probably about a third are behind us. But I think you have to -- I think a better way to look at this is that most of the pricing deterioration occurred in the first and second quarter. And then, it stabilized somewhere between, I think we said 7% to 15%. So as you get through the second quarter with pricing stabilized, we really shouldn't see any further deterioration. And if these volumes remain and improve a little bit, we may see some pricing power. Is that answering your question, Alex?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That's fair enough. I'll use my follow-up to sort of clarify, too. In a cycle, and I don't know if I should even use the word normal cycle, but if you go back to your experience in the business as we proceed, and let's assume utilization stays pretty good
componenttext: That's fair enough. I'll use my follow-up to sort of clarify, too. In a cycle, and I don't know if I should even use the word normal cycle, but if you go back to your experience in the business as we proceed, and let's assume utilization stays pretty good here and pricing is going to improve later in the year, what do you have to see in terms of spot pricing being up before the contract pricing turns up? And then, in the first year of recovery in pricing, contract pricing I'm talking about, assuming that's next year, how much pricing power do you get? I'm trying to get a feel for how long does it take and how should we think about recovery for your business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The great recession is a strange recession because I think that it leads to -- in the chemical refining business, the recovery was projected to be a lot slower than it in fact was. If you go back to the last recession, which began in 2000 through 2003, we
componenttext: The great recession is a strange recession because I think that it leads to -- in the chemical refining business, the recovery was projected to be a lot slower than it in fact was. If you go back to the last recession, which began in 2000 through 2003, we really didn't see any recovery until the end of 2003. Today, we're seeing a pretty sharp recovery. Now I think the dilemma is, do you believe it's sustainable? If it's sustainable then I would expect pricing actually to recover going forward a little quicker than it did in the last recession, the 2000 to 2003 recession. Spot prices are a leading indicator of contract pricing and today, spot pricing is actually slightly better than contracts as they're renewed. Now of course, contracts are renewed at lower rates. We said on average about 10% lower this quarter than last year's first quarter. But I think if you get spot pricing somewhere in the 5% to 10% range above contracts, they'll pull the contract pricing up. We're not there yet. I would say that -- when I say modestly above contract pricing, you're talking 3%, 4%. And you're also talking in an environment where they jump around a lot. There may be days where positioning drives spot pricing a little higher and other days where it depresses it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jon Chappell, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jon Chappell, JPMorgan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'm trying to think about the balance of the two issues that you talked about, both in this call and in calls previously to get the pricing environment stronger. Obviously volumes was part of it but then another big part of it was the removal of exce
componenttext: Joe, I'm trying to think about the balance of the two issues that you talked about, both in this call and in calls previously to get the pricing environment stronger. Obviously volumes was part of it but then another big part of it was the removal of excess capacity in the market. As the volumes have recovered, and I would probably guess it's sentiment across the industry, just as it has across the broader economy has improved over the last several months, do you think that people may hold on to their older barges a bit longer in the hopes to get one more strong pricing environment and that might put a ceiling on any pricing recovery, if the excess barge capacity isn't eliminated?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think that's going to happen. But of course, you just don't know. I think it's going to be driven by how quickly it firms up. There are all kinds of use of where this is all going but from our perspective, we continue to see over the year, a
componenttext: Yes, I don't think that's going to happen. But of course, you just don't know. I think it's going to be driven by how quickly it firms up. There are all kinds of use of where this is all going but from our perspective, we continue to see over the year, a pretty low GDP growth kind of environment. And that is going to put a damper on a lot more volume. The only thing that I think that might change that is that if we are experiencing in the petrochemical area, a pretty significant feedstock advantage with natural gas around $4 and crude oil around $85, and that disadvantages at petrochemicals and a lot of other areas in the world. So we're kind of coming -- well, we are globally competitive so the Export business is pretty firm. And that's a business that's very important to Kirby. It's less important to some of the other operators. It's hard to see how some of the other trades really enjoy significant volume improvements. I'm giving you kind of our view of how the economy drives volumes. And I think consistent with that view, I think that you'll see retirements. The older equipments are just expensive to operate, frankly. There are a number of customers, if they have a choice between a barge that's less than 20 years old versus a barge that's 35 years or older, they're going to prefer the younger barges. So there's kind of a natural selection process going on also. And the fact that this older equipment hang on was more driven by a pricing environment that I'd think we're ways away from getting to.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then for my follow-up, I want to stick with this whole improving sentiment theme. You had mentioned earlier this year, and I can't remember if it was in the fourth quarter call or at our conference in March, that asset price are still probably a littl
componenttext: And then for my follow-up, I want to stick with this whole improving sentiment theme. You had mentioned earlier this year, and I can't remember if it was in the fourth quarter call or at our conference in March, that asset price are still probably a little bit too high, hadn't come off enough from the '07 peak, and you thought that Kirby's next phase of growth would probably be a second half 2010, 2011 story. You're sitting with record levels of cash, at least, as far back as my model goes, which is like 12 years. Has the sentiment improvement in the group kind of changed the asset values or your thoughts about asset values? Do you think that maybe the bottom won't get as deep as you had originally thought, three, six months ago? And when do you start to pull the trigger on that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, it's not, not something that you have control over. You pull the trigger when the asset values are right. I think that the depth of the recession that we were thinking of clearly --  when we got there, we weren't there long, so recovery has
componenttext: Unfortunately, it's not, not something that you have control over. You pull the trigger when the asset values are right. I think that the depth of the recession that we were thinking of clearly --  when we got there, we weren't there long, so recovery has helped. But I also think that in low-growth environment, some of the enthusiasm for companies that have significant capital decisions in front of them or a lot of debt gets diminished and that there are going to be opportunities. I think that patience is in order. Back in the 90s were Kirby was pretty active from an acquisition perspective, that was the environment. It was a low-growth environment. So we're not less optimistic that there are going to be opportunities. We think that this is a business that is going to consolidate, and we think we're going to play a role in that consolidation. It's just hard to predict when it begins.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John [John Barnes] of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John [John Barnes] of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First on the capacity side, kind of a two-pronged question there. Number one, we saw Trinity announced an increase in its backlog and it seems like there's more crude activity going on right now. So I guess the question I have is, are you concerned at all
componenttext: First on the capacity side, kind of a two-pronged question there. Number one, we saw Trinity announced an increase in its backlog and it seems like there's more crude activity going on right now. So I guess the question I have is, are you concerned at all that this quick reversal, maybe it doesn't take capacity out, or maybe it does, the older equipment still goes away, but are you concerned at all that this quick recovery might lead to some increase in the order book and all of a sudden, a flood of capacity back into the market?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it depends on how quickly pricing comes back. Now the Trinity backlog is principally driven by us, so I'm terribly, terribly concerned about it. This just a good time to build tank barges. Prices are down, we have some replacement issues in f
componenttext: Yes, I think it depends on how quickly pricing comes back. Now the Trinity backlog is principally driven by us, so I'm terribly, terribly concerned about it. This just a good time to build tank barges. Prices are down, we have some replacement issues in front of us. We're just using this as an opportunity to upgrade our fleet when we think that new construction is priced attractively. So I guess, where we sit today, not really concerned about it if pricing took off. So I said before, capitalism works and you'll have some more additions. Now I'll also add that I think for companies that have significant amount of leverage, I think it's going to be very difficult to add more debt. And I think that this last cycle was a warning to all of us that these things happen and that the companies that do the best are the ones that are prudent with respect to how they capitalize their business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And secondly, I guess this is an extension of Jon's prior question on acquisitions. The A-rated balance sheet's great, it's a bonus. I think, we could argue whether or not it's necessary. And same thing, record levels of cash, funding CapEx from internall
componenttext: And secondly, I guess this is an extension of Jon's prior question on acquisitions. The A-rated balance sheet's great, it's a bonus. I think, we could argue whether or not it's necessary. And same thing, record levels of cash, funding CapEx from internally generated cash. I'm just kind of curious, the longer that the acquisitions scenario takes to play out, are you starting to give any thought to other uses of the cash? And more importantly, given where you stand today, do you think that you can maybe tackle more than one use of the cash, say, can still go to having the acquisitions scenario but maybe set aside part of the balance sheet or cash for either share repurchase, dividend, something along those lines?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is, you probably can. Our reluctance is really been driven by what we thought or what we think is a unique environment for potential acquisitions. But certainly, we have a lot of capacity on the balance sheet.
componenttext: The answer is, you probably can. Our reluctance is really been driven by what we thought or what we think is a unique environment for potential acquisitions. But certainly, we have a lot of capacity on the balance sheet.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You saw our debt-to-total cap ratio's 15.6% and clearly, we wouldn't mind being up in the 40% range, so we have a lot of capacity. As you saw, our debt's now $121 million -- I mean, our cash on the balance sheet's $121 million, so on a net debt basis, we'
componenttext: You saw our debt-to-total cap ratio's 15.6% and clearly, we wouldn't mind being up in the 40% range, so we have a lot of capacity. As you saw, our debt's now $121 million -- I mean, our cash on the balance sheet's $121 million, so on a net debt basis, we're 6.8% net debt-to-total cap. Lots of room, clearly, as Joe indicated, our preference would be an acquisition. But given our debt capacity and the cash, we certainly see the possibility of doing more than just acquisitions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jimmy [ph] of Rice Voelker.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jimmy [ph] of Rice Voelker.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The other part of that, of course, is supply chain disruptions that cause shippers to absorb more ton miles because you got to go to less -- well, you have to go longer distances to get the product that they need. Truthfully, I don't think we know. The ex
componenttext: The other part of that, of course, is supply chain disruptions that cause shippers to absorb more ton miles because you got to go to less -- well, you have to go longer distances to get the product that they need. Truthfully, I don't think we know. The export business has traditionally been 10% to 12% of the U.S. petrochemical volume. It got as low as 4% to 6%. We sense it's probably over the high end of the range as we speak and that's partly because of low feedstock cost. It's also partly because the dollar is okay, strengthening a little bit but still not to the point where it's disadvantaging exports. Now exports drive our business a lot less than domestic consumption. So even with the higher exports, the domestic consumption is going to be kind of our key driver. Jimmy [ph], that's probably a good question to ask towards the middle of the year, because we'll see how volumes do over the quarter. And I think we'll have a better sense for how much of it is truly improved demand. We couldn't tell you if you ask this question in January that there was crude demand. But today, we clearly think that there is real demand growth. But it's hard to predict how much.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We didn't give you that. The towboats operated averaged in the first quarter of 224, and that compares to 232 a year ago.
componenttext: Yes. We didn't give you that. The towboats operated averaged in the first quarter of 224, and that compares to 232 a year ago.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's all right on the last page of the release.
componenttext: It's all right on the last page of the release.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little of both, Jimmy [ph] (42:03). I would say about 30% of that number is chartered boats and the rest is owned.
componenttext: It's a little of both, Jimmy [ph] (42:03). I would say about 30% of that number is chartered boats and the rest is owned.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin [Kevin Sterling] of BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin [Kevin Sterling] of BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, are you done with your staff reductions? And will there be any more charges in the second quarter going forward?
componenttext: Joe, are you done with your staff reductions? And will there be any more charges in the second quarter going forward?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hope so. We sized Kirby to run our reduced fleet. We reduced our fleet by about 50 barges in 2009. We said we wanted to get to kind of 2009 levels with the ability to stretch up and handle the volume that our fleet could potentially handle. Now as
componenttext: Yes, we hope so. We sized Kirby to run our reduced fleet. We reduced our fleet by about 50 barges in 2009. We said we wanted to get to kind of 2009 levels with the ability to stretch up and handle the volume that our fleet could potentially handle. Now as utilization improves, you do add both. So I'm talking about really shore staff here. Now that doesn't suggest that if we had a deterioration in our business levels, you wouldn't go back and look at it. But we do think that we're staffed about where we need to be looking at current business levels and even improved -- some improvement in utilization.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So you can handle some more business without materially, I guess, increasing your staff or costs?
componenttext: So you can handle some more business without materially, I guess, increasing your staff or costs?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We can and we certainly can handle more price increases.
componenttext: We can and we certainly can handle more price increases.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Following up on Jimmy's [ph] (44:01) question about your towboats. With the increase in demand, are you having to outsource more power, or do you think you have ample tow capacity now?
componenttext: Following up on Jimmy's [ph] (44:01) question about your towboats. With the increase in demand, are you having to outsource more power, or do you think you have ample tow capacity now?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the nice thing about our power model is that you do have some flexibility around the charter fleet. You can add boats when you need them. But even this year, I think, that we're taking delivery of three new boats. And we have, I think, 10 boats or K
componenttext: Well, the nice thing about our power model is that you do have some flexibility around the charter fleet. You can add boats when you need them. But even this year, I think, that we're taking delivery of three new boats. And we have, I think, 10 boats or Kirby-owned boats, that are still tied up, so we can reach in and get those. The other thing that we've done during this period is we haven't stopped training pilots. We're continuing to train pilots. One to accommodate retirements, but also give us the ability to continue to crew our fleet at higher levels.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, you talked a little bit about demand continuing to improve to the month of April. Could you talk about your barge utilization through April?
componenttext: Joe, you talked a little bit about demand continuing to improve to the month of April. Could you talk about your barge utilization through April?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, our barge utilization in March, April was anywhere from the kind of the mid-80s to the high 80s. As weather improved, it tick down a little bit. That doesn't suggest that the volume is not there. What that says is that we're just doing it more effici
componenttext: Yes, our barge utilization in March, April was anywhere from the kind of the mid-80s to the high 80s. As weather improved, it tick down a little bit. That doesn't suggest that the volume is not there. What that says is that we're just doing it more efficiently, less delays, less weather delays. But it's currently in the -- I'd say, 87% range. I don't mind giving that number because we're doing it on a conference call. So it's down a little bit but nothing that we're particularly worried about. And anything over 85%, if you believe it's sustainable is good for pricing.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How would you describe or characterize industry capacity? It sounds like there's been a lot of talk of -- we're going to see capacity come out if pricing ticks up. It sounds like we're not at an equilibrium demand supply. How much excess supply do you thi
componenttext: How would you describe or characterize industry capacity? It sounds like there's been a lot of talk of -- we're going to see capacity come out if pricing ticks up. It sounds like we're not at an equilibrium demand supply. How much excess supply do you think there is right now in the industry?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We said in January that we thought that there were, I think, 300 to 400, too many barges and that included an estimate for barges that were being built. And that to get a balance and sustained pricing power that you really needed to either have those barg
componenttext: We said in January that we thought that there were, I think, 300 to 400, too many barges and that included an estimate for barges that were being built. And that to get a balance and sustained pricing power that you really needed to either have those barges removed or volumes need to be improved. We've seen some volume improvement based on the volumes that we're seeing. And again, I'm not suggesting that they're sustainable. We don't know. We hope they are. That number is going to be less, probably closer to a little less than 300 today. And what makes us, I think, optimistic that we can reach balance is that less barges are being built and the older barges are just very expensive to operate and we think they're going to retire. So even if we didn't see any volume growth over the next year or 18 months, I think, you'll continue to move the balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I believe you said you're adding 58 barges this year in 2010. Could you comment or did you say how many barges you would be retiring?
componenttext: Joe, I believe you said you're adding 58 barges this year in 2010. Could you comment or did you say how many barges you would be retiring?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is that -- and this was our January call, that we thought that we'd end the year with less barges, that the barges that we're building are replacement barges. But we were going to continue to look at that over the year and we'd make jud
componenttext: Well, what we said is that -- and this was our January call, that we thought that we'd end the year with less barges, that the barges that we're building are replacement barges. But we were going to continue to look at that over the year and we'd make judgments kind of around where we thought business was going. And that judgment would affect the total number of barges that we end up with.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chaz [Chaz Jones] of Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chaz [Chaz Jones] of Morgan Keegan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think every pricing and capacity question that anyone could come up with have been asked. But I guess, my question would center around margin and inland marine. Obviously, it sounds like fundamentals are in the process of bottoming, volumes getting a li
componenttext: I think every pricing and capacity question that anyone could come up with have been asked. But I guess, my question would center around margin and inland marine. Obviously, it sounds like fundamentals are in the process of bottoming, volumes getting a little bit better, pricing's close to bottoming out here. Have margins bottomed, I guess, is my question? Because typically, as we look at the first quarter, that's the seasonally low point for operating margins as well. So I'm just trying to think through, if we get a faster acceleration in pricing this cycle and we're starting at a 20% operating margin, where does this thing go in the next cycle?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start, will let David -- I think that your capability of extending your margin growth in the next cycle is greater than the last cycle, just because of the cost that you taken out of the business. And you'll also remember that the fuel, and I think y
componenttext: I'll start, will let David -- I think that your capability of extending your margin growth in the next cycle is greater than the last cycle, just because of the cost that you taken out of the business. And you'll also remember that the fuel, and I think you notice, Chaz, fuel has the ability to affect your margins just by the way that we account for it or charge for it through revenue. David, you want to comment?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Chaz, I guess, one way to think about this is back in 2000, we averaged -- and I'm going way back here to demonstrate kind of the highs and lows. In 2000, we ran in the Marine business at 18.9% margin. And then through the recession, it kind of dippe
componenttext: Yes. Chaz, I guess, one way to think about this is back in 2000, we averaged -- and I'm going way back here to demonstrate kind of the highs and lows. In 2000, we ran in the Marine business at 18.9% margin. And then through the recession, it kind of dipped down in 2003 to 14.6%, and then it slowly climbed back up. In 2009, you saw a 23.6%. So we're getting higher highs now and we'll have higher lows going forward, I think, because of the rightsizing of the organization. So you could expect an upward trend on margins if things stabilize and pricing improves. But to add to what Joe said, fuel does impact it. We don't make margin on it. It's kind of a pass-through. So it dilutes the margins a little bit, so you got to watch the fuel.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: Well, I've been on this conference call long enough to kind of remember when things started getting better in the last cycle, that Joe used to say, in the 70s, that Kirby ran at a mid-20s margin. And that just almost seems very conservative, if we do kind of get a strong V-shaped recovery in the economy the next couple of years.

componenttext: Well, based on the size of our fleet, we don't believe that we'll need to add shore staff. If the fleet grows, then you would. The exception to that is that in that 22%, there's also -- it include also some Kirby Engine Systems employees that you could argue -- our revenue producing in good times last year, they were not. That if that business grew in any kind of significant ways that you'd need to add employees there. But even so, we size that organization so that it could accommodate business levels that were 10%, 15% higher than they currently are.

componenttext: In shipyard construction?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's still a lot of shipyard capacity out there, and you can build more barges that are currently being built. And the order book for 2011 is minimal. We only know of, I don't know, maybe 10, 15 barges there potentially on the books. I mean, they
componenttext: Well, there's still a lot of shipyard capacity out there, and you can build more barges that are currently being built. And the order book for 2011 is minimal. We only know of, I don't know, maybe 10, 15 barges there potentially on the books. I mean, they haven't even been declared yet. So what affects construction is going to be how tight the manufacturing capacity is. And of course the cost of the material to build the barge and steel prices have risen. So there is those costs that are reflected in barges that you'd build in the future, so they're going to be up a little bit, but not up substantially. I'll just add that our appetite to build barges in this environment is driven by price. And if the price goes up to any significant degree, our appetite will quickly be diminished.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then going back to the kind of the replacement cycle for the aging of the fleet. I mean, is there a point where you see that kind of cascading forward a little bit in terms of the age in barges becoming a problem, and then maybe the manufacturing capa
componenttext: And then going back to the kind of the replacement cycle for the aging of the fleet. I mean, is there a point where you see that kind of cascading forward a little bit in terms of the age in barges becoming a problem, and then maybe the manufacturing capacity not being able to keep up with that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish our industry was -- that logic would control replacement cycles, but it doesn't. It's really driven by pricing. When pricing gets to the point where it's attractive to build, everybody goes out and builds and existing capacity remains. And then whe
componenttext: I wish our industry was -- that logic would control replacement cycles, but it doesn't. It's really driven by pricing. When pricing gets to the point where it's attractive to build, everybody goes out and builds and existing capacity remains. And then when pricing deteriorates, you see that older capacity disappear. So it's more a stair-step approach to building capacity and getting rid of it, versus a linear approach that's based on the age and condition of the fleet.

componenttext: Well, volumes are consistent kind of where they are. Our utilization is up from kind of a low to mid-80s to now the mid-80s to the high 80s. So that I would say utilization is up 5%, 6%. componenttext: Yes. Our contract to spot mix is 75% contract, 25% spot and that's where it was last quarter. And I would have said last quarter, I would expect it to continue to decline to its more traditional level which is 70%, 30%, but I'm not as confident of that. I think it will decline but whether it gets to 70%, I'm just not sure. Now with respect to time charters, those are the daily rate charters that we had so many of. I think, at its high, we had over 55% of our Contract business was under time charter. That continues to decline. The number that we gave out was, I think, 49% in the first quarter. And I actually expect that to continue to decline. I'm not even sure that we don't want it to decline a little bit, because with our large fleet and its capabilities. We do pretty well in the affreightment of business, because we just have more flexibility. We can use a barge that's positioned to load a cargo. We can use a bottom that's compatible with another cargo. We really can leverage our fleet a little better.

componenttext: Well, I think in the inland barge side of the business, we can manage our current barge fleet with essentially the people that we have. Now as utilization kicks up, you do have to add more vessels. And the exception might be that you'll need to add a few more maintenance people, or port captains or in the crewing area, but it's a relative de minimis amount compared to the total shore staff. With respect to the Diesel Engine business, we have geared that labor force to be able to handle maybe 10%, 15% more work. If you get more than that, then you'll have to add production people.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation
componenttext: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer. During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at kirbycorp.com in the Investor Relations section under non-GAAP financial data. Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's annual report on Form 10-K for the year-end December 31, 2009, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I will now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Late yesterday, we reported net earnings for the 2010 first quarter of $0.46 per share, compared with $0.52 per share reported for the 2009 first quarter. Included in our first quarter results was a previously announced $0.05 per share
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Late yesterday, we reported net earnings for the 2010 first quarter of $0.46 per share, compared with $0.52 per share reported for the 2009 first quarter. 
Included in our first quarter results was a previously announced $0.05 per share charge for retirements and shore staff reductions. Our 2009 first quarter results also included a $0.05 per charge for early retirements and shore staff reductions. 
Announced earnings guidance for the first quarter was $0.42 to $0.47 per share and included an estimated $0.04 per share costs for shore staff redundancies. The actual charge that we incurred in the first quarter was slightly higher, a $0.05 charge. 
During the 2010 first quarter, our Marine Transportation volumes improved, compared to both the 2009 first and fourth quarters. Our barge utilization for the first quarter, which is always impacted by weather, averaged in the mid-80s to high-80 range, above all four 2009 quarter levels and frankly, better than forecasted. 
In addition to increased petrochemical production, the improvement in our barge utilization level was also helped by some supply-chain disruptions caused by petrochemical and refraining plant turnarounds, as well as some unscheduled plant maintenance. Our higher volumes were also driven by improved demand for exported petrochemicals. 
U.S. petrochemical complex is enjoying a feedstock advantage today due to a relatively low natural gas costs in the U.S. compared to current crude oil prices. During the first quarter, the term contract portion of our revenue mix remained at about 75% contract, 25% spot. 
Our time charters represented a little less than 50% of total term contracts, compared to the 52% time charter mix we reported in the fourth quarter. While some customers have switched to spot freight in the contracts when their time charters have expired, others have just taken shorter charters of equipment as they're not ready to commit longer-term positions at this point. 
With improved volumes and resulting higher barge utilization rates during the first quarter, we did see pricing stabilize. Term contracts that were renewed during the first quarter generally decreased on average approximately 10% when compared with the term contracts that were renewed first quarter of 2009, with some firming in the contract areas as the quarter progressed. 
Spot contract rates for the first quarter, which of course include fuel and fuel was higher, were down 15% to 25% compared with first quarter spot pricing. But when compared to the fourth quarter, were up 3% to 6%. Again, this represents, I think, the stabilization of pricing in our business. 
With respect to the multi-year contracts that were typically renewed first of the year and escalated first of the year, these are contracts that don't expire in any given year. They're escalated for labor and either the producer price index or the consumer price index. The pricing was neutral for 2010. Typically in previous years, we've gotten anywhere from a 3% to 5% increase. 
The tank barge industry still has some excess capacity. Certainly, the demand that was experienced 2007, 2008, encouraged the industry to build new equipment. But also it encouraged the industry to keep older equipment and service, which typically would've been retired, to meet the higher demand levels. 
In 2009, 192 tank barges were delivered. We estimate about 140 barges were retired in 2009 for a net addition to the industry of about 50 barges. As of the beginning of 2010, we estimate there are approximately 3,150 tank barges in the industry, of which 500 are 35 years old and approximately 250 are 40 years old. 
For 2010, we believe that less than 100 barges will be constructed. Of those less than 100 barges, 58 are going to be ordered by Kirby. With respect to the barges that Kirby isn't building, a number of the barges being built in 2010 were in fact ordered for delivery in 2009 deferred into 2010. And the shipper is also building nine barges for his proprietary fleet serving his internal needs. 
Given the Asia profile of the industry fleet, we continue to expect older barges to be removed from service, and the industry supply versus demand will continue to move closer to balance. We're certainly encouraged by our improved utilization and the pricing stabilization that we're seeing. Demand is better as measured by the volumes that were moving. 
Certainly, demand is better than it was in 2009, and a little better than we thought it would be. However, we do expect our utilization to decline somewhat as weather improves and the supply chain becomes more efficient. This is not untypical in usual years, in late spring and in the summer, you typically see the industry utilization decline a little bit. 
The difference in 2007, 2008 was that there was so much demand that the industry was just fully utilized the entire year. During the 2010 first quarter, this is -- I'm talking about the Diesel Engine business, that segment demand levels for service and direct part sales generally remained weak across the majority of its markets, particularly, the high-speed oil service market. 
We did benefit from some first quarter seasonal work that we generally see in the Midwest and Great Lakes area for medium-speed marine customers. Our service customers continue to defer major maintenance, and this is in the oil service area. The medium-speed power generation market remained healthy, and our medium-speed railroad market benefited from improved direct part sales, as the utilization level for our railroad customers' equipment slowly improved, really reflecting improvements in demand for what they're producing. We do believe demand has bottomed out, but we still haven't seen any consistent signs of improvement in this business segment yet. I'll come back and talk more about this, as well as the outlook for the Inland Tank Barge business later in this call, but first, let me turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you Joe. As we disclosed in our press release, we continue to focus our attention on operating as prudently and as efficiently as possible. We did this by further reducing our cost in order to remain competitive as we try and
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you Joe. As we disclosed in our press release, we continue to focus our attention on operating as prudently and as efficiently as possible. We did this by further reducing our cost in order to remain competitive as we try and emerge from this economic downturn. 
In January 2010, we further reduced our Marine Transportation and corporate staffs through retirements and reductions, and we took a $4.1 million before-tax charge or $0.05 per share charge in the quarter. We took a similar early retirement and reduction charge in 2009 first quarter. Since our peak headcount in October 2008, we've reduced our shore staff headcount by 22% through early retirements, staff reductions and attritions. 
Kirby's Marine Transportation operating income was 8% below the 2009 first quarter and the operating margin of 19.3% was below the 2009 first quarter margin of 21%. Adjusting for the staff reduction charges in both quarters, the first quarter margin for this quarter would've been 20.5% compared with 22.3% for the first quarter in 2009. 
The lower margin reflected the impact of lower-term and spot-contract pricing throughout the last three quarters of 2009, some higher fuel prices and some more difficult operating conditions with weather and whatnot, partially offset by the benefit of the cost reductions from the headcount reductions that we initiated. The Diesel Engine Services operating income was in line with last year's first quarter. The operating margin was 10.4%. 
This compared with 8.7% reported for the 2009 first quarter or 11.1% adjusted for early retirements and staff reductions taken in the first quarter of 2009. Customers continue to defer their diesel engine maintenance projects, resulting in continued low labor utilization for the business. 
We have a strong cash flow generation quarter. EBITDA was $66 million in the quarter, and as of quarter end at March 31, we had $121 million in cash or in cash equivalents. Our capital spending for the first quarter totaled $34 million, which included $21 million for new tank barges and towboats and $13 million, primarily for capital upgrades to the existing fleet. 
Our capital spending guidance for 2010 remains in the range of $125 million to $135 million, which includes approximately $60 million for new tank barges and towboat construction. During the 2010 first quarter, we took delivery of 16 new 10,000-barrel and two 30,000-barrel tank barges, which added about 226,000 barrels of capacity. 
However, we also retired tank barges in the quarter, 20. And that reduced our overall capacity by 365,000 barrels. So net-net our capacity declined about 139,000 barrels during the quarter. As of March 31, we operated 861 tank barges with the total capacity of 16.6 million barrels. This compares with our peak tank barge count of 918 back in June 30 of 2008, and a peak capacity of about 17.5 million barrels. 
So this reflects a 6% reduction from the peak number of tank barges we operate and about a 5% reduction from our peak tank barge capacity. For the remainder of 2010, as we have stated before, to take advantage of attractive barge construction prices and to continue to upgrade our fleet and provide our customers with newer equipment, we will take delivery of 37 new 10,000-barrel barges, three 30,000-barrel barges and five new 10,000-barrel chartered barges, which will add about 530,000 barrels of capacity. 
However, we will continue to retire older tank barges from the fleets. So with that now, I'll turn it back to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. I'll turn to the outlook for the second quarter and the year. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our second quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share, which compares to $0.63 per share earned in the second quarter of last year. If you
componenttext:
Thank you, David. I'll turn to the outlook for the second quarter and the year. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our second quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share, which compares to $0.63 per share earned in the second quarter of last year. If you take the $0.46 per share, first quarter earnings, which reflected some modest improvement in volumes, add back the $0.05 per share staff reduction charge and look for some improvement in weather and operating conditions, you're basically at the low end of our range, the $0.52 level. 
The $0.57 high end of the range assumes that we continue to see Transportation volumes improve somewhat. We're forecasting for the Diesel Engine business kind of flat operating results, similar to other results in the first quarter. 
As for the full year, based on a more positive outlook for the balance of the year, we're raising our low-end guidance to $2, up from the $1.85 that we put out at the beginning of the year. And we're maintaining our high-end guidance of $2.20 per share. 
Our previous $1.85 low-end guidance assumed 2010 volumes would be consistent with volumes in 2009 and continued downward pressure on term contract renewals and spot contract pricing, at least, through the first half of the year. Fortunately, during the first quarter, volumes improved at contract and spot market pricing stabilized. And with respect to spot prices, we're, in fact, up a little. 
Therefore, the new $2 low-end guidance assumes volumes are going to be stable for the remainder of 2010, and that pricing is going to remain about where it is. Our $2.20 high-end guidance assumes continued modest improvement in volumes as the year progresses and a continued reduction in the current number of tank barges, a reduction in capacity. This all combining to lead to some modest improvement in term and spot pricing in the second half of the year. 
As we stated in last quarter's call, to achieve pricing power, barge capacity will need to be removed from the industry fleet where volumes will need to improve to absorb existing capacity or a combination of both will need to happen. We did see some improvement in volumes during the quarter. And time will tell whether, frankly, these volumes are sustainable. If they are sustainable, we suspect that we will see some modest pricing power in the second half of 2010. 
Now Kirby is in great financial shape. We've taken significant amount of cost out of our business last year, early this year. We have a very strong balance sheet, low level of debt, favorable interest rates and cash on our balance sheet that should continue to build. In March of this year, S&P increased our credit rating from a BBB+ to a investment grade rated A-. 
So we remain in excellent position to execute our objective of making strategic acquisitions as they become available. Also I want to comment, before we open the call up to questions, on -- for the retirement of Berdon Lawrence, Kirby's Chairman of the Board since 1999. 
Yesterday, Berdon retired. He has announced that he was going to retire on October of last year. I would like to thank Berdon, publicly, for his service not only to Kirby, but to the inland tank barge industry. He has truly been a leader of this industry and has helped guide Kirby to its success while serving as Kirby's Chairman. I have enjoyed working with Berdon over the past 10 years, beginning with the integration of Hollywood into Kirby and continuing over those years with Kirby's strategy of enhancing and growing our core businesses through synergistic acquisitions, and also creating enhanced earnings and value for our shareholders. 
Fortunately, Berdon is not going to go far. He is going to serve on Kirby's board. He's going to be Kirby's Chairman Emeritus and we'll still have access to his wisdom. Operator, I think we're now ready to open the call up for questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Alex [Alexander Brand] of Stephens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
