componenttext: My first question is, help us understand, since I guess the beginning of '09, but when pricing turned down, what percentage of the contracts have been renewed and so that pricing down is behind us and what's still to come?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As of today, probably about a third are behind us. But I think you have to -- I think a better way to look at this is that most of the pricing deterioration occurred in the first and second quarter. And then, it stabilized somewhere between, I think we sa
componenttext: As of today, probably about a third are behind us. But I think you have to -- I think a better way to look at this is that most of the pricing deterioration occurred in the first and second quarter. And then, it stabilized somewhere between, I think we said 7% to 15%. So as you get through the second quarter with pricing stabilized, we really shouldn't see any further deterioration. And if these volumes remain and improve a little bit, we may see some pricing power. Is that answering your question, Alex?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That's fair enough. I'll use my follow-up to sort of clarify, too. In a cycle, and I don't know if I should even use the word normal cycle, but if you go back to your experience in the business as we proceed, and let's assume utilization stays pretty good
componenttext: That's fair enough. I'll use my follow-up to sort of clarify, too. In a cycle, and I don't know if I should even use the word normal cycle, but if you go back to your experience in the business as we proceed, and let's assume utilization stays pretty good here and pricing is going to improve later in the year, what do you have to see in terms of spot pricing being up before the contract pricing turns up? And then, in the first year of recovery in pricing, contract pricing I'm talking about, assuming that's next year, how much pricing power do you get? I'm trying to get a feel for how long does it take and how should we think about recovery for your business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The great recession is a strange recession because I think that it leads to -- in the chemical refining business, the recovery was projected to be a lot slower than it in fact was. If you go back to the last recession, which began in 2000 through 2003, we
componenttext: The great recession is a strange recession because I think that it leads to -- in the chemical refining business, the recovery was projected to be a lot slower than it in fact was. If you go back to the last recession, which began in 2000 through 2003, we really didn't see any recovery until the end of 2003. Today, we're seeing a pretty sharp recovery. Now I think the dilemma is, do you believe it's sustainable? If it's sustainable then I would expect pricing actually to recover going forward a little quicker than it did in the last recession, the 2000 to 2003 recession. Spot prices are a leading indicator of contract pricing and today, spot pricing is actually slightly better than contracts as they're renewed. Now of course, contracts are renewed at lower rates. We said on average about 10% lower this quarter than last year's first quarter. But I think if you get spot pricing somewhere in the 5% to 10% range above contracts, they'll pull the contract pricing up. We're not there yet. I would say that -- when I say modestly above contract pricing, you're talking 3%, 4%. And you're also talking in an environment where they jump around a lot. There may be days where positioning drives spot pricing a little higher and other days where it depresses it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jon Chappell, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jon Chappell, JPMorgan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'm trying to think about the balance of the two issues that you talked about, both in this call and in calls previously to get the pricing environment stronger. Obviously volumes was part of it but then another big part of it was the removal of exce
componenttext: Joe, I'm trying to think about the balance of the two issues that you talked about, both in this call and in calls previously to get the pricing environment stronger. Obviously volumes was part of it but then another big part of it was the removal of excess capacity in the market. As the volumes have recovered, and I would probably guess it's sentiment across the industry, just as it has across the broader economy has improved over the last several months, do you think that people may hold on to their older barges a bit longer in the hopes to get one more strong pricing environment and that might put a ceiling on any pricing recovery, if the excess barge capacity isn't eliminated?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think that's going to happen. But of course, you just don't know. I think it's going to be driven by how quickly it firms up. There are all kinds of use of where this is all going but from our perspective, we continue to see over the year, a
componenttext: Yes, I don't think that's going to happen. But of course, you just don't know. I think it's going to be driven by how quickly it firms up. There are all kinds of use of where this is all going but from our perspective, we continue to see over the year, a pretty low GDP growth kind of environment. And that is going to put a damper on a lot more volume. The only thing that I think that might change that is that if we are experiencing in the petrochemical area, a pretty significant feedstock advantage with natural gas around $4 and crude oil around $85, and that disadvantages at petrochemicals and a lot of other areas in the world. So we're kind of coming -- well, we are globally competitive so the Export business is pretty firm. And that's a business that's very important to Kirby. It's less important to some of the other operators. It's hard to see how some of the other trades really enjoy significant volume improvements. I'm giving you kind of our view of how the economy drives volumes. And I think consistent with that view, I think that you'll see retirements. The older equipments are just expensive to operate, frankly. There are a number of customers, if they have a choice between a barge that's less than 20 years old versus a barge that's 35 years or older, they're going to prefer the younger barges. So there's kind of a natural selection process going on also. And the fact that this older equipment hang on was more driven by a pricing environment that I'd think we're ways away from getting to.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then for my follow-up, I want to stick with this whole improving sentiment theme. You had mentioned earlier this year, and I can't remember if it was in the fourth quarter call or at our conference in March, that asset price are still probably a littl
componenttext: And then for my follow-up, I want to stick with this whole improving sentiment theme. You had mentioned earlier this year, and I can't remember if it was in the fourth quarter call or at our conference in March, that asset price are still probably a little bit too high, hadn't come off enough from the '07 peak, and you thought that Kirby's next phase of growth would probably be a second half 2010, 2011 story. You're sitting with record levels of cash, at least, as far back as my model goes, which is like 12 years. Has the sentiment improvement in the group kind of changed the asset values or your thoughts about asset values? Do you think that maybe the bottom won't get as deep as you had originally thought, three, six months ago? And when do you start to pull the trigger on that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, it's not, not something that you have control over. You pull the trigger when the asset values are right. I think that the depth of the recession that we were thinking of clearly --  when we got there, we weren't there long, so recovery has
componenttext: Unfortunately, it's not, not something that you have control over. You pull the trigger when the asset values are right. I think that the depth of the recession that we were thinking of clearly --  when we got there, we weren't there long, so recovery has helped. But I also think that in low-growth environment, some of the enthusiasm for companies that have significant capital decisions in front of them or a lot of debt gets diminished and that there are going to be opportunities. I think that patience is in order. Back in the 90s were Kirby was pretty active from an acquisition perspective, that was the environment. It was a low-growth environment. So we're not less optimistic that there are going to be opportunities. We think that this is a business that is going to consolidate, and we think we're going to play a role in that consolidation. It's just hard to predict when it begins.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John [John Barnes] of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John [John Barnes] of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First on the capacity side, kind of a two-pronged question there. Number one, we saw Trinity announced an increase in its backlog and it seems like there's more crude activity going on right now. So I guess the question I have is, are you concerned at all
componenttext: First on the capacity side, kind of a two-pronged question there. Number one, we saw Trinity announced an increase in its backlog and it seems like there's more crude activity going on right now. So I guess the question I have is, are you concerned at all that this quick reversal, maybe it doesn't take capacity out, or maybe it does, the older equipment still goes away, but are you concerned at all that this quick recovery might lead to some increase in the order book and all of a sudden, a flood of capacity back into the market?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it depends on how quickly pricing comes back. Now the Trinity backlog is principally driven by us, so I'm terribly, terribly concerned about it. This just a good time to build tank barges. Prices are down, we have some replacement issues in f
componenttext: Yes, I think it depends on how quickly pricing comes back. Now the Trinity backlog is principally driven by us, so I'm terribly, terribly concerned about it. This just a good time to build tank barges. Prices are down, we have some replacement issues in front of us. We're just using this as an opportunity to upgrade our fleet when we think that new construction is priced attractively. So I guess, where we sit today, not really concerned about it if pricing took off. So I said before, capitalism works and you'll have some more additions. Now I'll also add that I think for companies that have significant amount of leverage, I think it's going to be very difficult to add more debt. And I think that this last cycle was a warning to all of us that these things happen and that the companies that do the best are the ones that are prudent with respect to how they capitalize their business.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And secondly, I guess this is an extension of Jon's prior question on acquisitions. The A-rated balance sheet's great, it's a bonus. I think, we could argue whether or not it's necessary. And same thing, record levels of cash, funding CapEx from internall
componenttext: And secondly, I guess this is an extension of Jon's prior question on acquisitions. The A-rated balance sheet's great, it's a bonus. I think, we could argue whether or not it's necessary. And same thing, record levels of cash, funding CapEx from internally generated cash. I'm just kind of curious, the longer that the acquisitions scenario takes to play out, are you starting to give any thought to other uses of the cash? And more importantly, given where you stand today, do you think that you can maybe tackle more than one use of the cash, say, can still go to having the acquisitions scenario but maybe set aside part of the balance sheet or cash for either share repurchase, dividend, something along those lines?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is, you probably can. Our reluctance is really been driven by what we thought or what we think is a unique environment for potential acquisitions. But certainly, we have a lot of capacity on the balance sheet.
componenttext: The answer is, you probably can. Our reluctance is really been driven by what we thought or what we think is a unique environment for potential acquisitions. But certainly, we have a lot of capacity on the balance sheet.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You saw our debt-to-total cap ratio's 15.6% and clearly, we wouldn't mind being up in the 40% range, so we have a lot of capacity. As you saw, our debt's now $121 million -- I mean, our cash on the balance sheet's $121 million, so on a net debt basis, we'
componenttext: You saw our debt-to-total cap ratio's 15.6% and clearly, we wouldn't mind being up in the 40% range, so we have a lot of capacity. As you saw, our debt's now $121 million -- I mean, our cash on the balance sheet's $121 million, so on a net debt basis, we're 6.8% net debt-to-total cap. Lots of room, clearly, as Joe indicated, our preference would be an acquisition. But given our debt capacity and the cash, we certainly see the possibility of doing more than just acquisitions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jimmy [Jimmy Gibert] [ph] of Rice Voelker.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jimmy [Jimmy Gibert] [ph] of Rice Voelker.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The other part of that, of course, is supply chain disruptions that cause shippers to absorb more ton miles because you got to go to less -- well, you have to go longer distances to get the product that they need. Truthfully, I don't think we know. The ex
componenttext: The other part of that, of course, is supply chain disruptions that cause shippers to absorb more ton miles because you got to go to less -- well, you have to go longer distances to get the product that they need. Truthfully, I don't think we know. The export business has traditionally been 10% to 12% of the U.S. petrochemical volume. It got as low as 4% to 6%. We sense it's probably over the high end of the range as we speak and that's partly because of low feedstock cost. It's also partly because the dollar is okay, strengthening a little bit but still not to the point where it's disadvantaging exports. Now exports drive our business a lot less than domestic consumption. So even with the higher exports, the domestic consumption is going to be kind of our key driver. Jimmy [ph], that's probably a good question to ask towards the middle of the year, because we'll see how volumes do over the quarter. And I think we'll have a better sense for how much of it is truly improved demand. We couldn't tell you if you ask this question in January that there was crude demand. But today, we clearly think that there is real demand growth. But it's hard to predict how much.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And also, you guys had been giving a number of power vessels operated in the quarter versus the number of power vessels operated in the prior year's quarter? And maybe I missed that, but could you give that number? And have you been on yourself re-leasing
componenttext: And also, you guys had been giving a number of power vessels operated in the quarter versus the number of power vessels operated in the prior year's quarter? And maybe I missed that, but could you give that number? And have you been on yourself re-leasing or putting idle towboats back in the service? And if so, how many?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't give you that. The towboats operated averaged in the first quarter 224, and that compares to 232 a year ago.
componenttext: We didn't give you that. The towboats operated averaged in the first quarter 224, and that compares to 232 a year ago.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's all right on the last page of the release.
componenttext: It's all right on the last page of the release.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So are you re-leasing or this is a re-leasing of towboats, or are you putting idle boats that you own back into service?
componenttext: So are you re-leasing or this is a re-leasing of towboats, or are you putting idle boats that you own back into service?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little of both, Jimmy. I would say about 30% of that number is chartered boats and the rest is owned.
componenttext: It's a little of both, Jimmy. I would say about 30% of that number is chartered boats and the rest is owned.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin [Kevin Sterling] of BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin [Kevin Sterling] of BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, are you done with your staff reductions, and will there be any more charges in the second quarter going forward?
componenttext: Joe, are you done with your staff reductions, and will there be any more charges in the second quarter going forward?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hope so. We sized Kirby to run our reduce fleet. We reduced our fleet by about 50 barges in 2009. We said we wanted to get to kind of 2009 levels with the ability to stretch up and handle the volume that our fleet could potentially handle. Now as
componenttext: Yes, we hope so. We sized Kirby to run our reduce fleet. We reduced our fleet by about 50 barges in 2009. We said we wanted to get to kind of 2009 levels with the ability to stretch up and handle the volume that our fleet could potentially handle. Now as utilization improves, you do add both. So I'm talking about really sure staff here. Now that doesn't suggest that if we had the deterioration in our business levels, you wouldn't go back and look at it. But we do think that we're staffed about where we need to be looking at current business levels and even improved -- some improvement in utilization.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So you can handle some more business without materially, I guess, increasing your staff or cost?
componenttext: So you can handle some more business without materially, I guess, increasing your staff or cost?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We can and we certainly can handle more price increases.
componenttext: We can and we certainly can handle more price increases.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Following-up on Jimmy's question about your towboats, with the increase in demand, are you having to outsource more power, or you think you have ample tow capacity now?
componenttext: Following-up on Jimmy's question about your towboats, with the increase in demand, are you having to outsource more power, or you think you have ample tow capacity now?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the nice thing about our power model is that you do have some flexibility around the charter fleet. You can add boats when you need them. But even this year, I think that we're taking delivery of three new boats. And we have, I think, 10 boats that
componenttext: Well, the nice thing about our power model is that you do have some flexibility around the charter fleet. You can add boats when you need them. But even this year, I think that we're taking delivery of three new boats. And we have, I think, 10 boats that are Kirby-owned boats, that are still tied up, so we can reach in and get those. The other thing that we've done during this period is we haven't stopped training pilots. We're continuing to train pilots. We want to accommodate retirements, but also give us the ability to continue to crew our fleet at higher levels.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, you talked a little bit about demand continuing to improve to the month of April. Could you talk about your barge utilization through April?
componenttext: Joe, you talked a little bit about demand continuing to improve to the month of April. Could you talk about your barge utilization through April?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, our barge utilization in March, April was anywhere from the kind of the mid-80s to the high 80s. As weather improved, it tick down a little bit. That doesn't suggest that the volume is not there. What that says is that we're just doing it more effici
componenttext: Yes, our barge utilization in March, April was anywhere from the kind of the mid-80s to the high 80s. As weather improved, it tick down a little bit. That doesn't suggest that the volume is not there. What that says is that we're just doing it more efficiently, less delays, less weather delays. But it's currently in the 87% range. I don't mind giving that number because we're doing it on a conference call. So it's down a little bit but nothing that we're particularly worried about. And anything over 85%, if you believe it's sustainable is good for pricing.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How would you describe or characterize industry capacity? It sounds like there's been a lot of talk of we're going to see capacity come out off pricing ticks up. It sounds like we're not at an equilibrium of demand/supply. How much excess supply do you th
componenttext: How would you describe or characterize industry capacity? It sounds like there's been a lot of talk of we're going to see capacity come out off pricing ticks up. It sounds like we're not at an equilibrium of demand/supply. How much excess supply do you think there is right now in the industry?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We said in January that we thought that there were, I think, 300 to 400 too many barges. And that included an estimate for barges that where being built. And that to get a balance and sustained pricing power that you really needed to either have those bar
componenttext: We said in January that we thought that there were, I think, 300 to 400 too many barges. And that included an estimate for barges that where being built. And that to get a balance and sustained pricing power that you really needed to either have those barges removed or volumes need to be improved. We've seen some volume improvement based on the volumes that we're seeing. And again, I'm not suggesting that they're sustainable. We don't know. We hope they are. That number is going to be less, probably closer to a little less than 300 today. And what makes us, I think, optimistic that we can reach balance is that less barges are being built and the older barges are just very expensive to operate and we think they're going to retire. So even if we didn't see any volume growth over the next year or 18 months, I think, you'll continue to move to balance.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I believe you said you're adding 58 barges this year in 2010? Could you comment or did you say how many barges you would be retiring?
componenttext: Joe, I believe you said you're adding 58 barges this year in 2010? Could you comment or did you say how many barges you would be retiring?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is that -- and this was our January call, that we thought that we'd end the year with less barges, that the barges that we're building are replacement barges. But we were going to continue to look at that over the year and we'd make jud
componenttext: Well, what we said is that -- and this was our January call, that we thought that we'd end the year with less barges, that the barges that we're building are replacement barges. But we were going to continue to look at that over the year and we'd make judgments kind of around where we thought business was going. And that judgment would affect the total number of barges that we end up with.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chaz [Chaz Jones] of Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chaz [Chaz Jones] of Morgan Keegan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think every pricing and capacity questions that anyone could come up with have been asked. But I guess, my question would center around margin in inland marine. Obviously, it sounds like fundamentals are in the process of bottoming, volumes are getting
componenttext: I think every pricing and capacity questions that anyone could come up with have been asked. But I guess, my question would center around margin in inland marine. Obviously, it sounds like fundamentals are in the process of bottoming, volumes are getting a little bit better, pricing's close to bottoming out here. Have margins bottomed, I guess, is my question? Because typically, as we look at the first quarter, that's the seasonally low point for operating margins as well. So I'm just trying to think through, if we get a faster acceleration in pricing this cycle and we're starting at a 20% operating margin, where does these thing go in the next cycle?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that your capability of extending your margin growth in the next cycle is greater than the last cycle, just because of cost that you've taken out of the business. You'll also remember that the fuel, I think you notice, Chaz, fuel has the ability t
componenttext: I think that your capability of extending your margin growth in the next cycle is greater than the last cycle, just because of cost that you've taken out of the business. You'll also remember that the fuel, I think you notice, Chaz, fuel has the ability to affect your margins just by the way that we account for it or charge for it through revenue. David, you want to comment?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Chaz, I guess, one way to think about this is, back in 2000, we averaged -- and I'm going way back here to demonstrate kind of the highs and lows. In 2000, we ran in the Marine business at 18.9% margin. And then through the recession, it kind of dipped do
componenttext: Chaz, I guess, one way to think about this is, back in 2000, we averaged -- and I'm going way back here to demonstrate kind of the highs and lows. In 2000, we ran in the Marine business at 18.9% margin. And then through the recession, it kind of dipped down in 2003 to 14.6%, and then it slowly climbed back up. In 2009, you saw a 23.6%. So we're getting higher highs now and we'll have higher lows going forward, I think, because of the rightsizing of the organization. So you could expect an upward trend on margins if things stabilize and pricing improves. But to add to what Joe said, fuel does impacted it. We don't make margin on it. It's kind of a pass-through. So it dilutes the margins a little bit, so you got to watch the fuel.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I've been on this conference call long enough to kind of remember when things started getting better in the last cycle that Joe used to say, in the 70s, that Kirby ran at a mid-20s margin. And that just almost seems very conservative if we do kind o
componenttext: Well, I've been on this conference call long enough to kind of remember when things started getting better in the last cycle that Joe used to say, in the 70s, that Kirby ran at a mid-20s margin. And that just almost seems very conservative if we do kind of get a strong V-shaped recovery in the economy the next couple of years.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If you get a V-shaped, sure. I don't know if you're going to get a V-shaped. But you got to layer your forecast of where you think this is all going on that. But in that scenario, a V-shaped sharp recovery, you could see margin certainly in that area.
componenttext: If you get a V-shaped, sure. I don't know if you're going to get a V-shaped. But you got to layer your forecast of where you think this is all going on that. But in that scenario, a V-shaped sharp recovery, you could see margin certainly in that area.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess my follow up on that, does your guidance assume that margins get better in the back half of the year?
componenttext: I guess my follow up on that, does your guidance assume that margins get better in the back half of the year?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, marginally.
componenttext: Yes, marginally.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike [Michael Baudendistel] of Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike [Michael Baudendistel] of Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the shore staff. You're down 22% from the peak in 2008. If volumes were to recover back to where you were running peak volumes, I wonder if you had an estimate of how many of those shore staff reductions will be sustainable?
componenttext: I had a question on the shore staff. You're down 22% from the peak in 2008. If volumes were to recover back to where you were running peak volumes, I wonder if you had an estimate of how many of those shore staff reductions will be sustainable?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Based on the size of our fleet, we don't believe that we'll need to add shore staff. If the fleet grows, then you would. The exception to that is that in that 22%, there's also -- it include also some Kirby Engine Systems employees that you could argue ou
componenttext: Based on the size of our fleet, we don't believe that we'll need to add shore staff. If the fleet grows, then you would. The exception to that is that in that 22%, there's also -- it include also some Kirby Engine Systems employees that you could argue our revenue producing in good times last year, they were not. That if that business grew in any kind of significant ways, you would need to add employees there. But even so, we size that organization so that it could accommodate business levels that were 10%, 15% higher than they currently are.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: On the equipment side, it's my understanding that you guys have been more aggressive than your competitors, taking delivery of barges because the cost to take delivery of those barges is low at the moment. I'm wondering if you've seen any increase in thos
componenttext: On the equipment side, it's my understanding that you guys have been more aggressive than your competitors, taking delivery of barges because the cost to take delivery of those barges is low at the moment. I'm wondering if you've seen any increase in those cost here recently as volumes have picked up?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In shipyard construction?
componenttext: In shipyard construction?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's still a lot of shipyard capacity out there, and you could build more barges that are currently being built. And the order book for 2011 is minimal. We only know of, I don't know, maybe 10, 15 barges there potentially on the books. I mean, th
componenttext: Well, there's still a lot of shipyard capacity out there, and you could build more barges that are currently being built. And the order book for 2011 is minimal. We only know of, I don't know, maybe 10, 15 barges there potentially on the books. I mean, they haven't even been declared yet. So what affects construction is going to be how tight the manufacturing capacity is. And of course the cost of the material to build the barge and steel prices have risen. So there is those costs that are reflected in barges that you'll build in the future, so they're going to be up a little bit, but not up substantially. I'll just add that our appetite to build barges in this environment is driven by price. And if price goes up to any significant degree, our appetite will quickly be diminished.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve [Stephen O'Hara] of Sidoti & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve [Stephen O'Hara] of Sidoti & Company.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: Or total transportation market. You can move these volumes by different modes of transportation. But we think that we can get bigger. Where that exact number is, we don't know. We say that it's closer to 50% and than where we are today. But yes, we think we can continue to grow.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the kind of the replacement cycle for the aging of the fleet, I mean, is there a point were you see that kind of cascading forward a little bit in terms of the age in barges becoming a problem, and then maybe the manufacturing capacity not b
componenttext: Going back to the kind of the replacement cycle for the aging of the fleet, I mean, is there a point were you see that kind of cascading forward a little bit in terms of the age in barges becoming a problem, and then maybe the manufacturing capacity not being able to keep up with that?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish our industry was -- that logic would control replacement cycles, but it doesn't. It's really driven by pricing. When pricing gets to the point where it's attractive to build, everybody goes out and builds and existing capacity remains. And then whe
componenttext: I wish our industry was -- that logic would control replacement cycles, but it doesn't. It's really driven by pricing. When pricing gets to the point where it's attractive to build, everybody goes out and builds and existing capacity remains. And then when pricing deteriorates, you see that older capacity disappear. So it's more a stair-step approach to building capacity and getting rid of it, versus a linear approach that's based on the age and condition of the fleet.

componenttext: Well, volumes are consistent kind of where they are. And if you go back to the 2009 first quarter, the U.S. Petrochemical business was shutting itself down, so volumes are certainly recovering from that point. Our utilization is up from kind of a low to mid-80s to now the mid-80s to the high 80s. So that I would say utilization is up 5%, 6%. I would say it's more, I think, more single-digit growth levels as it's measured by our utilization.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: And how much of it is that Contracts? I'm just trying to get the visibility you have on the volumes.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our contract-to-spot mix is 75% contract, 25% spot. That's where it was last quarter. And I would have said last quarter, I would expect it to continue to decline to its more traditional level which is 70%, 30%, but I'm not as confident of that. I think i
componenttext: Our contract-to-spot mix is 75% contract, 25% spot. That's where it was last quarter. And I would have said last quarter, I would expect it to continue to decline to its more traditional level which is 70%, 30%, but I'm not as confident of that. I think it will decline but whether it gets to 70%, I'm just not sure. Now with respect to time charters, those are the daily rate charters that we had so many of. I think, at it's high, we had over 55% of our Contract business was under time charter. That continues to decline. The number that we gave out was, I think, 49% in the first quarter. And I actually expect that to continue to decline. I'm not even sure that we don't want it to decline a little bit, because with our large fleet, its capabilities, we do pretty well in the affreightment of business, because we have more flexibility. We can use a barge that's positioned to load a cargo, we can use a bottom that's compatible with another cargo. We really can leverage our fleet a little better.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up would be on the cost side. You talked a bit about the shore staff, the reductions that you've made. When do you, looking forward, I think you start to bring some of that in?
componenttext: And then my follow-up would be on the cost side. You talked a bit about the shore staff, the reductions that you've made. When do you, looking forward, I think you start to bring some of that in?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the inland barge side of the business, we can manage our current barge fleet with essentially the people that we have. Now as utilization kicks up, you do have to add more vessels. The exception might be that you'll need to add a few more mainten
componenttext: Well, in the inland barge side of the business, we can manage our current barge fleet with essentially the people that we have. Now as utilization kicks up, you do have to add more vessels. The exception might be that you'll need to add a few more maintenance people, or port captains or in the crewing area, but it's a relative de minimis amount compared to the total shore staff. With respect to the Diesel Engine business, we have geared that labor force to be able to handle maybe 10%, 15% more work. If you get more than that, then you'll have to add production people.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Kirby Corporation's Second Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's conference. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Steve Holcomb, Vice President, Investor
componenttext: Welcome to the Kirby Corporation's Second Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's conference. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Steve Holcomb, Vice President, Investor Relations. Mr. Holcomb, you may begin.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer.During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. With me is Joe Pyne, Kirby's Chief Executive Officer; and David Grzebinski, our Chief Financial Officer.
During this conference call, we may refer to certain non-GAAP or adjusted financial measures. A reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures is available on our website at kirbycorp.com, in the Investor Relations section under non-GAAP financial data. 
Statements contained in this conference call with respect to the future are forward-looking statements. These statements reflect management's reasonable judgment with respect to future events. Forward-looking statements involve risk and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated as a result of various factors. A list of these risk factors can be found in Kirby's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
I will now turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Steve. Yesterday, we reported 2010 second quarter net earnings of $0.54 a share compared to our 2009 second quarter net earnings of $0.63 per share. Our announced earnings guidance for the second quarter was $0.52 to $0.57 per share. For
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Steve. Yesterday, we reported 2010 second quarter net earnings of $0.54 a share compared to our 2009 second quarter net earnings of $0.63 per share. Our announced earnings guidance for the second quarter was $0.52 to $0.57 per share. For the first six months of 2010, we earned $1 per share compared to $1.15 per share, same period a year before.
During the second quarter, our Marine Transportation demand and barge utilization were in line with the first quarter, above the comparable levels in 2009 and above frankly what we anticipated at the beginning of this year. Our barge utilization for the second quarter averaged in the mid to high-80% range, remaining above all four 2009 quarter levels. And we suspect our utilization level is, on average, better than the industry average. This improvement in demand and utilization was driven by modestly higher refinery and petrochemical outlet. The higher volumes were also driven by improved demand for export petrochemicals. U.S. petrochemicals continued to enjoy a feedstock advantage due to their relatively low natural gas costs compared to higher crude-based systems.
Increase in the second quarter Marine Transportation revenue was primarily due to higher diesel fuel prices, averaging 60% higher than the 2009 second quarter, as the higher fuel price is passed to customers through fuel escalation and de-escalation causes which are embedded in our term agreements. 
During the 2010 second quarter, the term contract portion of our revenue mix remained at 75%. That's 75% contracts, 25% in the spot market. Time charters represented a little better than 50% of total of term contracts during the quarter compared to about the same number last quarter. While some customers have switched to spot affreightment agreements when the time charter contracts expire, others have shortened their charter exposure, as we're not ready to take longer-term position on equipment at this time.
With modestly improved volumes and resulting higher barge utilization rates during the first half of the year, pricing has stabilized. This is encouraging. Unfortunately, there is still uncertainty with respect to the economy, sustainability of demand and equipment utilization, which is affecting the industry's appetite to test raising rates. 
Consequently, term contracts that were renewed during the second quarter were relatively flat with the first quarter renewals, but decreased, on average, 10% to 12% when compared with term contract rate renewals, second quarter of last year. Spot contract rates for the second quarter, which include the price of fuel, were up 2% to 3% compared with the first quarter, but down 10% to 15% when you compare them to the same period last year. 
With respect to our annual renewals effective January 1, 2010, on our multiyear issued contracts of over a year, the escalators were essentially neutral, not positive or negative. 
During the second quarter, our Diesel Engine Service segment saw continued weak service and parts sales and some pricing pressure, principally in the high-speed market, across marine markets, again, principally in the Gulf Coast area servicing the Oil Service business. 
As customers continued to defer major maintenance projects, our Gulf Coast high-speed market did see some modest benefit during the quarter from acquired repair service for customer's equipment involved in the Gulf Coast cleanup effort. But customers are generally just patching. They're not doing the kind of the long-term overhauls that really drive this business. 
The medium-speed power generation market continued to remain stable, but our second quarter results were impacted by fewer generator engine set upgrade projects and lower direct part sales. Pricing in this business continues to remain stable. 
Our Medium-speed Railroad business benefited from improved direct part sales, as utilization levels for our railroad customers improved slightly over the first half of the year.
With respect to the BP oil spill and its effect on our transportation sector, it really has been minimal. We have cleaned oil from only one tow operating in the inland waterwaste (sic) [wastewater] system since the beginning of the spill. And in our offshore operations, at most, we've sustained only minor increased transit times as we avoided oil slicks during Gulf crossings between Louisiana and Florida. We are aware of several of our competitors using some inland tank barges in the cleanup efforts. This certainly has helped the industry tank parts utilization during the quarter, but it hasn't been enough to improve pricing. 
Our Diesel Engine Service segment high-speed Gulf Coast operations, as I mentioned earlier, did benefit from required repairs to equipment used in the cleanup efforts. However, the moratorium on the deepwater drilling will impact companies servicing the Gulf Coast Oil and Gas business. Currently, about 20% to 25% of our Diesel Engine Service revenues are associated with the Gulf Coast Oil and Gas Drilling business, including both the shallow water and deepwater drilling. 
At this point, it's very difficult to know the future financial impact of this moratorium or, frankly, the effect of new regulations on drilling operators and what that effect is going to mean for diesel engine service sector. 
I'll come back at the end of our prepared remarks and talk about our forecast for the third quarter and the full year outlook. But I'll now turn the call over to David.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Let me provide a few more details on the quarter. Kirby's Marine Transportation revenue was 6% above and operating income 7% below the second quarter of 2009. The segment's operating margin was 21.6% compared with 24.4% from the prior year
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Let me provide a few more details on the quarter. Kirby's Marine Transportation revenue was 6% above and operating income 7% below the second quarter of 2009. The segment's operating margin was 21.6% compared with 24.4% from the prior year period. The lower margin reflected the impact of lower term and spot contract pricing throughout the last three quarters of 2009 and the first half of 2010. Higher fuel prices and increased delay days also impacted margins. Partially offsetting this was the benefit of the ongoing cost-reduction efforts and efficiency initiatives that we implemented throughout 2009 and the early part of 2010. So year-over-year, pricing and margins are down, but pricing is stabilizing, as Joe mentioned, and margins have improved sequentially from the first quarter. 
In the Diesel Engine Services business, revenue was 21%, income 45% below last year's second quarter. The operating margin was 9.5% compared with 13.6% reported in the second quarter of last year. The lower results in margins primarily reflected the continued weak Gulf Coast oil service high-speed markets, as Joe mentioned, as customers defer major maintenance projects. 
We were also affected by fewer engine generator set upgrades and lower direct parts sales in the Power Generation market. The lower industry-wide business activity is placing some downward pressure on pricing. With the lower labor utilization, lower pricing, the results are impacting Diesel Engine Services operating margins.
We continue to generate significant cash during the second quarter. Our EBITDA was $73 million for the quarter, and for the first six months were at $139 million. At June 30, we had $141 million in cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet. Our capital spending for the first six months has totaled $68 million, which includes $35 million for new tank barge and towboat construction and $33 million primarily for capital upgrades to the existing fleet. 
We did raise our capital spending guidance for 2010 to a range of $135 million to $145 million, and this includes $70 million for new tank barge and towboat construction. The increased capital spending guidance was primarily due to expected prepayments for 2011 new barge construction. 
In June, we contracted for the construction of 25 new 30,000-barrel barges for delivering in 2011. Our current plans are not to expand the fleet and to use these new barges to replace older equipment, which we will remove from service. New construction capital expenditures for 2011 are currently projected to be in the range of $50 million to $60 million, and that's based on the current commitments and current steel prices and current delivery schedules.
During the first half of 2010, we took delivery of 29 new 10,000-barrel tank barges, three 30,000-barrel barges and five new 10,000-barrel chartered tank barges. This added 462,000 barrels of new capacity. However, offsetting that, during the first half, we retired 40 tank barges, which reduced our overall capacity by 643,000 barrels. So net-net, our capacity declined 181,000 barrels during the first half. As of June 30, we operated 860 barges with a capacity of 16.5 million barrels, and this compares to our peak back in June of 2008 of 918 barges and a capacity of 17.5 million barrels. For the remainder of 2010, we will take delivery of 24 new 10,000-barrel barges and three 30,000-barrel barges which will add 336,000 barrels of new capacity. However, again, we continue and will continue to retire older tank barges from the fleet. 
During June 2010 and through the day before yesterday, we've purchased 171,000 shares of Kirby common stock at an average price of $39.30, and we did this under a 10b5-1 stock trading plan. The 10b5-1 program is applicable for our second, third and year end Kirby imposed blackout periods, and we currently have 1,230,000 shares remaining under our previously authorized share repurchase authorization. However, in July of this year, the board approved an additional 2 million share repurchase authorization, and that brings our total repurchase authorization to 3,230,000 shares. 
I'll now turn the call back to Joe.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, David. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our 2010 third quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share compared with $0.65 per share earned the same period the year before. For the year, we updated our guidance to $2.03 to $2.13. Our low en
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, David. Yesterday afternoon, we announced our 2010 third quarter guidance of $0.52 to $0.57 per share compared with $0.65 per share earned the same period the year before. For the year, we updated our guidance to $2.03 to $2.13. Our low end $0.52 per share third quarter guidance and the $2.03 per share year guidance assumes volumes and equipment utilization will remains stable with the volumes and utilization during the first half of this year, and term and spot contract rates will remain relatively flat. Now the high end of our guidance of $0.57 per share and for the third quarter and a $2.13 for the year assumes a modest improvement in volumes in the second half of the year and a continued reduction in the industry-wide excess tank barge capacity, leading to some improvement in pricing for both the term and contracts.
Both our low-end and high-end guidance assumes our Diesel Engine Service operation will continue to face challenges, particularly in that part of the business that services Gulf Coast Oil business. Now our challenge is to move pricing. Frankly, it's not so much volumes. It's the price that we can charge to move those volumes, that is the issue today. 
If utilization remains at current levels and the industry remains disciplined with respect to capacity and the market regains some confidence, pricing will occur. Confidence will be driven by seeing the economies stabilize during the second half of the year and when more clarity is seen with respect to the legislative and regulatory environment in Washington.  
Kirby remains in excellent financial shape. We've taken a significant amount of cost out of our business. We have a every strong balance sheet, low debt levels, favorable interest rates and cash on our balance sheet which should continue throughout this year. We remain in an excellent position to take advantage of both synergistic acquisitions, should they become available, and to repurchase our stock. We find ourselves in the enviable position of having a balance sheet fully capable of doing both, buying assets and buying stock. 
Operator, we'll now open the call to questions.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Alex Brand from Stephens Inc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Alex Brand from Stephens Inc.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, can you give us some color, particularly the market, I guess, is not happy with your guidance and the top end coming down? What factored into that? I mean, what did you guys see that changed in the quarter? And was it more about the diesel business b
componenttext: Joe, can you give us some color, particularly the market, I guess, is not happy with your guidance and the top end coming down? What factored into that? I mean, what did you guys see that changed in the quarter? And was it more about the diesel business being so weak? Or did something change your outlook on the barge side as well?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the Diesel business certainly played into it, but also pricing. I think that we need some pricing to move the numbers materially. Although spot pricing is up a little bit. When you adjust it for fuel, it's still pretty anemic. I think that what's ne
componenttext: Well, the Diesel business certainly played into it, but also pricing. I think that we need some pricing to move the numbers materially. Although spot pricing is up a little bit. When you adjust it for fuel, it's still pretty anemic. I think that what's needed is the confidence that goes along with raising prices. At least at this point, we haven't seen it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In this environment, I mean, obviously, you want to put the balance sheet to work, and you'd rather do it with acquisitions than stock buyback. Is this good? I mean, is it now -- it's stabilized, but it's still not that great an environment. But is that t
componenttext: In this environment, I mean, obviously, you want to put the balance sheet to work, and you'd rather do it with acquisitions than stock buyback. Is this good? I mean, is it now -- it's stabilized, but it's still not that great an environment. But is that the right environment for acquisitions?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Alex, let me answer it this way. I think the environment is still good. If pricing improves, all boats are going to be lifted. But if it remains anemic, we think that the environment will, in fact, improve. Now what I did mention on the call in April is t
componenttext: Alex, let me answer it this way. I think the environment is still good. If pricing improves, all boats are going to be lifted. But if it remains anemic, we think that the environment will, in fact, improve. Now what I did mention on the call in April is that based on, kind of just on the fundamentals in the economy, it's hard to see that in the next several years, we're going to go into a high-growth environment. I mean, I think people are projecting relatively modest growth. We think that is, in fact, conducive to acquisitions because it takes a lot of the fun out of the business. And this is a business where you focus on servicing your customers being safe and controlling your cost. That's hard work. That was the environment that we saw in the kind of early to middle '90s. We continue to believe that over the next couple of years that the business is going to consolidate, and we're going to play a part in it.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jon Chappell from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jon Chappell from JPMorgan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I want to ask you a bigger strategic question. You've done a lot of acquisitions over the last several years on the Diesel Engine Services side; and now it appears that, that business has been exceptionally weak, six straight quarters of double-digit
componenttext: Joe, I want to ask you a bigger strategic question. You've done a lot of acquisitions over the last several years on the Diesel Engine Services side; and now it appears that, that business has been exceptionally weak, six straight quarters of double-digit year-over-year top line declines, seven straight quarters of double-digit year-over-year operating income declines. Has something structurally changed with that business? Or is this just a function of the slowdown in the broader economy? And is there a potential restructuring or a way you're looking at this business differently going forward and given the recent results?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a fair question, Jon. It's certainly has been challenging. The moratorium on Gulf drilling is something that has to concern us. But even before that, there were declines. And the declines were principally in the high-speed business, wh
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a fair question, Jon. It's certainly has been challenging. The moratorium on Gulf drilling is something that has to concern us. But even before that, there were declines. And the declines were principally in the high-speed business, which are more focused on the Oil service business. So you really saw a deterioration in drilling that was occurring even before the moratorium. Now what gave us hope was that most of our customers were forecasting increased levels of drilling in and around the Gulf Coast; principally because until the BP spill, the political environment was much more stable, and the ability to make money in drilling per -- the drilling in the Gulf of Mexico was more predictable. So the though was that, that part of the business would get stronger in the latter part of the year and continue to improve, which led us to assume that there really wasn't anything structurally going wrong. It was just really more of a matter of timing. Having said that, the moratorium clearly changes that, and we have to kind of step back and say, "Where is that business going?" One of the things that we are positioning ourselves to do, and we have done to a certain extent before, is to follow our customers overseas. That's going to be an important component to reverse the negative trends in that business. We have already reduced staffing in that business. We're down in excess of 20% in terms of headcount from the high several years ago. But to get it going back on track, something has to happen in the Oil Service business; either the moratorium gets lifted, we start drilling again; or we leverage our position in that business to move offshore.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-up question shifts back just to the broader balance sheet question. You mentioned earlier, and I think it's even before the first quarter conference call in April, that asset prices were probably still a little bit too high for your liking. I me
componenttext: My follow-up question shifts back just to the broader balance sheet question. You mentioned earlier, and I think it's even before the first quarter conference call in April, that asset prices were probably still a little bit too high for your liking. I mean, it hadn't come down enough in the 2007, early 2008 peak, given everything that happened in the business. Given more than mixed economic data and maybe a little bit less near-term optimism, have asset prices corrected to the point where you think you're closer than you've been in the last couple of years...

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, I think so. But I think we also said that the companies who became available in this direct environment, a distressed environment, they're the ones that don't have another choice. I mean, you always want to sell in a favorable market than resist sel
componenttext: John, I think so. But I think we also said that the companies who became available in this direct environment, a distressed environment, they're the ones that don't have another choice. I mean, you always want to sell in a favorable market than resist selling in a distressed market. Having said that, it just takes time to have the industry realize that some of the really high prices paid for marine assets were poorly timed and not appropriate. And that, that is gone. That ability to sell at those levels is gone. It's not going to come back. And I think that's happening. And I think that probably there is some buyer's remorse, frankly, with respect to some people that pay the prices that were paid several years ago. And that ultimately, you're going to get back to rational pricing levels that are going to be able -- that we're going to get excited about.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jimmy Gilbert (sic) [Gibert] from Rice Voelker, LLC.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jimmy Gilbert (sic) [Gibert] from Rice Voelker, LLC.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it's my impression that your customers were fairly positive in the last part of Q1 and early Q2, and it seems like they were fairly anxious to book freight. And I guess in the back end of Q2, they kind of slowed a bit. And I guess you hear a lot a
componenttext: I guess it's my impression that your customers were fairly positive in the last part of Q1 and early Q2, and it seems like they were fairly anxious to book freight. And I guess in the back end of Q2, they kind of slowed a bit. And I guess you hear a lot about in inventory restocking effect. And when you talk to your customers, is that the effect that you're seeing? And when do you think that cycle might restart again?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Jimmy, we think inventories are still pretty low. I think our customers think they're low. We certainly didn't see in our utilization rates any market slowdown. I mean, you don't have a week or two which is a little slower than another week. So I'm not su
componenttext: Jimmy, we think inventories are still pretty low. I think our customers think they're low. We certainly didn't see in our utilization rates any market slowdown. I mean, you don't have a week or two which is a little slower than another week. So I'm not sure we're seeing what you're alluding to. But let me make this point. At least with respect to kind of the volumes that we're seeing, our problem isn't volume. It's price. We're seeing enough volume. It's just being able to move rates that affect your bottom line, and we're having problems doing that. Again, as I said in the call, I mean that's going to come. It's going to come as you build confidence in the sustainability of all of this. We already said we were surprised that the volumes were higher than projected at the beginning of the year. That's very favorable. But there is still this lingering doubt that the U.S. economy, although is better, still has a way to go before it sees any strength.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I know you guys watch your costs very carefully and as you mentioned, you've taken your cost down quite a bit. And do you think there is more room to go on that front? Are there opportunities? I guess, there always are opportunities. But how mean
componenttext: And then I know you guys watch your costs very carefully and as you mentioned, you've taken your cost down quite a bit. And do you think there is more room to go on that front? Are there opportunities? I guess, there always are opportunities. But how meaningful are they going forward?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that we've done most of the significant cost-reduction initiatives based on the environment as we see it. You can take almost too much cost out of a business, lose the ability to respond to the market or compromise your service or safety le
componenttext: Well, we think that we've done most of the significant cost-reduction initiatives based on the environment as we see it. You can take almost too much cost out of a business, lose the ability to respond to the market or compromise your service or safety levels. And we certainly did set against that. Having said that, you're always looking at what's happening in the market. If we conclude that the market is going to deteriorate, then we'll fine-tune our cost plan.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Kevin Sterling from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Kevin Sterling from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, just kind of getting back to this cycle. Have there been other times in your history when your utilization has exceeded the industry but there's not been a positive impact on pricing for you? Can you talk maybe a little bit how this cycle might be a
componenttext: Joe, just kind of getting back to this cycle. Have there been other times in your history when your utilization has exceeded the industry but there's not been a positive impact on pricing for you? Can you talk maybe a little bit how this cycle might be a little different, given that fact? Because usually when your utilization is above 80%, 85%, pricing's in your favor.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it should be. I can't remember, in my working career, an environment that had so much uncertainty in it. There's certainly been other periods where you're concerned about going into a recession. But here, we're reportedly coming out of a recessio
componenttext: Yes, and it should be. I can't remember, in my working career, an environment that had so much uncertainty in it. There's certainly been other periods where you're concerned about going into a recession. But here, we're reportedly coming out of a recession. But we're just looking at so many changes that we really don't understand the implications to. And you have, coming out of this recession, very high unemployment. All of the traditional vehicles that were used to stimulate the economy have already been used. I don't want to play economist, but in kind of our simple world, the barge world, I think that the industry kind of looks at all this stuff and says, "We don't know what's going to happen." And when you don't have clarity with respect to what's going to happen, I think you tend to be more conservative. I actually think it's as simple as that. I think if we could get some clarity with respect to what's going to happen if utilization rates remain at these levels, that we should get some pricing. And you're seeing that in other parts of the economy. It just hasn't got to us yet. Now I'll also tell you that I think, at least with respect to Kirby, if you look at our performance over this period, it's been pretty stable. And the other thing to just remind the listeners is that our operating margins are north of 20%, and that in itself probably is remarkable. You would typically see more stress with respect to operating margins. We've been able to cost controls, just working hard to service our customers in a really flat-rate environment to continue hold the margins up. So to me, that's pretty positive. The last recession that we went into, the 2000 recession, I think the margins were down in the 14% range.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up question, as we look at the industry, you've been talking about the excess supply, and I think that's clearly a factor. Are you seeing industry participants retire older equipment? Or are they trying to run their equipment longer? Is that e
componenttext: As a follow-up question, as we look at the industry, you've been talking about the excess supply, and I think that's clearly a factor. Are you seeing industry participants retire older equipment? Or are they trying to run their equipment longer? Is that exasperating the supply situation? And if that's the case, because you guys have such a young fleet, I assume that gives you a competitive advantage as well. Just what are you seeing in the industry in terms of guys trying to maybe run their equipment a little longer and really try to hold on to volumes?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our fleet actually, Jimmy (sic) [Kevin],  is about the industry average. Some of it's young. Some of it's not so young, which is why we're continuing to build through this to make it younger. I think that there are retirements occurring. There were retire
componenttext: Our fleet actually, Jimmy (sic) [Kevin],  is about the industry average. Some of it's young. Some of it's not so young, which is why we're continuing to build through this to make it younger. I think that there are retirements occurring. There were retirements in 2009 which we can measure, and I would expect that, that trend's going to continue. That the fleet's going to balance. We're not that long, when you think about it. Kevin, if you assume that -- let's say, the industry average is about 80%, below 80s, you've got 200 to 300 barges that need to come out. There's not that many barges that can happen pretty quickly. So I'm not concerned about capacity so much. I mean, I think capacity matters with pricing, certainly. I think our problem is as much confidence and all this is sustainable. That the volumes are sustainable, and we can get over that. I think we can raise prices.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Hoexter from Bank of America.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

Joe, just following on your comments regarding the uncertainty in the environment, are you seeing contract customers positioning themselves differently in negotiations? And is there a big desire to shift towards spot-based pricing for the near term or over the next 12 to 24 months?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think our customers are as confused as we are. I mean, we're not really seeing that. Our contract spot mark mix is stayed at about 75%. I think it may work its way down a little bit, maybe as the pricing cycle begins, but I don't think it'll get below 7
componenttext: I think our customers are as confused as we are. I mean, we're not really seeing that. Our contract spot mark mix is stayed at about 75%. I think it may work its way down a little bit, maybe as the pricing cycle begins, but I don't think it'll get below 70%. Time charters are still relatively high, about 50% of our business. I don't think our customers really have any better clarity than we do. Their volumes are certainly better, which is encouraging. And they're doing better, which is also encouraging.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just looking on the Diesel segment, was the increased Gulf activity and cleanup more of a net positive during the quarter? Did the moratorium really impact demand at all on a short-term basis during this 2Q?
componenttext: And just looking on the Diesel segment, was the increased Gulf activity and cleanup more of a net positive during the quarter? Did the moratorium really impact demand at all on a short-term basis during this 2Q?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No. It certainly was positive, but it did not offset what we'd normally see, which is a major repair work. What you're seeing is kind of patching and not -- let's take the vessel down and do a complete overhaul. Let's just keep it running a little bit and
componenttext: No. It certainly was positive, but it did not offset what we'd normally see, which is a major repair work. What you're seeing is kind of patching and not -- let's take the vessel down and do a complete overhaul. Let's just keep it running a little bit and see what happens.

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: So you would expect a big catchup once the moratorium lifts, kind of...

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. That should happen. If the moratorium lifts, we put drilling rigs back to work. That should be positive. But depending on what kind of regulations are put out there, assuming they're not so onerous that it inhibits drilling, my guess is that's
componenttext: Yes, I do. That should happen. If the moratorium lifts, we put drilling rigs back to work. That should be positive. But depending on what kind of regulations are put out there, assuming they're not so onerous that it inhibits drilling, my guess is that's probably going to help too.

componenttext: And I get that, and I know you don't have a crystal ball. But assuming that industry utilization is below where Kirby is and the outlook for the next couple of years is this "slower growth environment," how long does it take to get 200 to 300 barges of excess capacity out of the market, assuming that's what we're working with here?

componenttext: It shouldn't take that long because of the age profile of the fleet. And again, I think pricing is as much about confidence right now as it is about capacity. If you could tell the industry, you, Chaz Jones, could tell the industry that we're in for modest growth the next two to three years, 2%, 3%, there is no risk that all the bills that have been passed in Congress are going to affect us and that we're not going to -- there's no risk of also another recession, I think that you'd have pricing as we speak.

componenttext: I was wondering in terms of the, I guess, the uncertainty in the environment, I mean, is there is anything different in terms of what you are seeing going forward now other than the political environment and possibly in the Gulf? I mean, is there anything on a macro level that is maybe more bearish than it was back in April?

headline: Kirby Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that it's just kind of more of the same. You have continued action by the U.S. Congress pushing stuff out, and I can't tell you if it's positive or negative. The Gulf Coast moratorium certainly is something that is new and not positive.
componenttext: Well, I would say that it's just kind of more of the same. You have continued action by the U.S. Congress pushing stuff out, and I can't tell you if it's positive or negative. The Gulf Coast moratorium certainly is something that is new and not positive. I don't think there is anything that makes us more bearish. Remember, we forecasted this year at $1.85 to $2.20. We adjusted the forecast from $2 to $2.20, and now we're just fine-tuning it to $2.03 to $2.13. And we have put the parameters around where we think we're going to be based on, principally pricing. And if we were to get pricing on the next month or so, we might well even exceed the 2013. But we put out our guidance as kind of our best estimate, and we can be wrong. But we've always taken the position that we think that the market deserves our perspective, and then to try to color that perspective so that they kind of understand our thinking. And that's what we have out there.

componenttext: I mean, I guess it's kind of not necessarily that you guys are any more bearish. componenttext: I would not want to make that a blanket statement. I mean, some are, some aren't. Each company has their own view of the market and acts accordingly. In a market where there is a consensus that it's strengthening, then everybody's pushing rates. When you have an environment such as we're in now, it's all over the board.
